PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and Senators in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, strongly urge that the Australian Government prohibit the entry of nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered vessels into Australian ports or waters during our bicentennial celebrations and at any other time in the future.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them, for cost saving reasons only, on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra Bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that is is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia Respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.

that Australia is one nation which comprises people from many different racial and cultural backgrounds;

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Relocation of Transylvanian Village Dwellers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia wish to draw to the attention of Honourable Senators the cynical and cruel oppression of ethnic minorities in Transylvania by the Romanian Government through the forceful relocation of village dwellers so that their villages can be demolished and used for collective farms.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament should urge the Australian Government to put diplomatic pressure on the Romanian Government to refrain from this savage act and leave these unfortunate people in their villages where they and their forefathers lived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Casino Control Ordinance 1988, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 72 of 1988, made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed.

Five times in the last 12 years-in 1977, 1979, 1981, 1983 and now in 1988-a casino has been proposed for Canberra. Each time so far, the clear opposition of the residents of Canberra has killed the proposal. The opposition to a casino has not been simply because Canberra residents do not want this sort of development in their own backyard, with all its associated problems. The opposition to a casino has come from people all over Australia who have an ideal or a vision of how the nation's capital should be. Both these groups of Australians have been consistently ignored and insulted in the current casino debate.

In the first place, the Australian Democrats believe that a decision of such importance to a community must be made by the people in that community. I remind honourable senators that it is to be hoped that in the very near future the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) will have its own Assembly to make this sort of decision. This time the ACT casino proposal was dreamed up by the then Minister, Mr John Brown, who introduced it into the major section 19 development proposal for the city of Canberra.

There was no consultation with the local community-not even, I believe, with the locally elected representatives for the ACT. On 18 April 1988, I asked a question in this place of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories. I asked whether the Minister was aware of the results of a poll conducted by a Canberra newspaper. The Minister said in his answer that one should read the results of any poll in conjunction with the reading of the methodology adopted in the poll.

I must admit that I have criticised some polls myself, regarding them as shonky. I make no claims for the precise accuracy of the newspaper poll in question, the results of which were published on 23 February this year. I would allow considerable leeway in interpreting these results. I would accept that the methodology adopted by the pollsters tends to bring out those people of strong views while leaving the silent majority unmoved. Having said all this, I believe that no Minister could ignore a sample of 2,500 residents of whom 77 per cent voted `no casino'. I suggest that the Minister's caution about these results was quite reasonable. But I also suggest that the Minister's figures for the casino, provided in answer to one of my questions earlier this year-he referred to millions of dollars and thousands of jobs-need even more caution. But I will return to the costs and benefits of the casino later.

Why do the people of Canberra object to the notion of a casino? It is easy enough to brush their objections aside and say they are negative, opposed to developments or anti-everything. One time Territories Minister Punch, speaking to Pru Goward on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation morning show in March of this year said:
Well, I think some of these issues have got to be explained, Pru. I mean, this opposition to the casino is, I think, more wowser based than anything else. I think that's what it's all about.

That was the public view of the Minister responsible for the ACT, Gary Punch, who said that opposition is wowser based. There may be some so-called wowsers out there who oppose the casino. There may be a large group of people who presumably the Minister would describe as wowsers-that is, people who sincerely believe that gambling in itself is wrong. I guess that those of us who oppose the casino find ourselves in strange mixed company. The so-called wowsers who oppose the casino include Senator John Stone, all those people who love Canberra for the gracious city that it is but who see a casino as totally inappropriate for such a city, and 68 per cent of members of the ACT branch of the Liberal Party. I would like to quote a letter which was written on 1 July 1977 during an earlier casino campaign by Sir Robert Menzies to J. H. Bradbury. It states:
My Government engaged in a lot of hard thought, and some little imagination, for the purpose of making Canberra a Capital City of which all Australians could be proud.

I am horrified to find that proposals are now being made to establish a Casino in Canberra. Such an establishment would, no doubt, attract some gambling tourists and, in a small way, convert Canberra into a sort of Las Vegas. Nothing could be more inconsistent with the existence of a dignified National Capital. I therefore hope that you will have success in your campaign, in which I am entirely on your side.

My feelings about the matter at issue are very strong, because I have been foolish enough to think that the development of Canberra as a real National Capital might be regarded as one of my better deeds.

The proponents of the ACT casino, who appear to include the developers themselves, representatives of some parts of the building industry, along with certain members of the Labor Government, have gone to some pains to persuade us that the people of the ACT want a casino as part of the overall development of the central Civic area. In August of this year the Canberra Association for Regional Development, known as CARD, commissioned McNair Anderson to conduct a survey on its behalf. Once again I remind honourable senators of the caution given by Senator Richardson about the methodology of polls. However, the usually reliable Canberra Times on Friday, 2 September had a heading on page 1 which stated `Most favour Civic project'. On page 2 the headline became `Majority favour casino'. I remind honourable senators of the poll result. While a clear majority of Canberrans strongly favoured the further development of the city centre and especially the development of a theatre and a library, an equally clear majority specified that the feature about the proposal which they specially disliked was `the casino'; so the casino is especially disliked. All honourable senators as well as members of the other place who conscientiously read their incoming mail will recall a letter dated 19 August of this year. It reads:
We, the undersigned are opposed to a casino for Canberra, and call for the casino ordinance to be disallowed.

There were more than 30 signatories to this letter. The signatories were representative of the most influential groups in the community. They represent some of the people whom the ex-Minister denigrated as wowsers. The signatories include the President of the Baptist churches; the Administrator of the Anglican Church Diocese; the Chairman of the Canberra Presbytery of the Uniting Church in Australia; the Catholic Archbishop of Canberra; the chairperson of the ACT Women's Consultative Committee; the director of the ACT Council of Social Service; the secretary of the ACT National Council of Women; the principal counsellor of the Australian National University; the spokeswoman of the Women's Electoral Lobby; and it goes on and on. In fact these people represent more than 30 organisations.

These people represent much of the responsible and caring opinion in Canberra. We are told by the casino proponents and a succession of Ministers that the casino is a good thing because it will bring prosperity to the city of Canberra. They tell us that any unpleasant consequences of having a casino would be more than outweighed by the benefits. This theory simply does not stand up to examination in the light of what has happened in other parts of Australia. Casinos are simply not economically as wonderful as the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) would have us believe.

The first Australian casino at Wrest Point in Tasmania-the first legal casino of course-has had a well documented history of boom and decline. While it is still paying its way, its contribution to the economy of Tasmania is far smaller than predicted. Its contribution to the quality of life in Hobart is debatable. There are casinos scattered all around Australia. There is no particular reason to suppose that a casino in Canberra would bring a single tourist to Canberra who is not coming to Canberra anyway. A casino is no longer a tourist draw in itself.

A tourist coming to Canberra who loses money at the casino in all probability-this is documented in Queensland-would cut short his Canberra visit rather than prolong it. The money going to the casino would be of less value to the local economy than if it were to be spent in some locally owned and managed enterprise. Casinos simply do not do as well in Australia as they have been expected to do. Honourable senators will recall that at the July conference in Canberra of the National Association of Gambling Studies, it was stated that casinos are not successful as a catalyst for international tourism. It was doubted whether domestic tourists travel specifically to visit a casino. Let us consider the market analysis offered by well known Sydney stockbrokers James Capel Rivkin, which referred in a document dated May 1987 to the three casinos-Jupiters on the Gold Coast, Breakwater in Townsville and Burswood in Perth:
The three listed casino trusts looked like good investments until they began to operate. The sharemarket's initial enthusiasm turned to disgust as all three failed to meet their prospectus forecasts.

Again and again the various Ministers over a series of years have claimed that the proposed library and theatre development cannot happen without a casino. I am persuaded absolutely that the Australian Capital Territory will benefit from having a lyric theatre despite reports in the Canberra Times earlier this year which stated:
Does Canberra need a 2000 seat theatre which would have been used nine times over the past two years-
according to Mr Dawkins's account-
For any `great city' more important than the size of its theatres is the quality of plays it can produce.

As I said, I am convinced that the Australian Capital Territory will benefit from having a lyric theatre. There is no rational, essential or logical connection between a casino and a theatre or a casino and a library. The Minister has challenged his critics to come up with the money for these developments if there is no casino. Do I have to remind the Minister that Canberra is the capital of Australia and that it should have, for this reason alone, cultural facilities as good as any in Australia for its own citizens and in order to be a showplace for the world. Even though the Minister asserts that relevant land values will be enhanced by the presence of a casino and that entrepreneurs will hurry to put in their bids, this is no more than an assertion.

I come now to the very important question of jobs. Certain sections of the building industry have been very vocal on the subject of jobs. The argument has often resembled the argument in defence of building that celebrated dam on the Franklin River; in other words, we must build the dam because otherwise the work force would be unemployed. However, there has never been an answer to the question: What will happen when it is finished? Of course, on the basis of this sort of argument a project can later turn out to have been misguided and misconceived from the start. If the building trades need a casino for jobs, what will they do when the casino is completed? Will they build another casino? If, as has been mooted, they would then be offered jobs on the proposed National Museum, for example, why not start that project now?

There are a number of alternatives of that sort. For example, there is the Royal Canberra Hospital, which notoriously is in need of refurbishing. Potentially there is the very fast train project and its associated infrastructure, to be provided, incidentally, by private enterprise. These are some of the areas which the building unions should be looking at. There is also the ongoing development of inner Canberra itself. If, after genuine community discussions, this is truly found to be necessary and desirable, for reasons other than of providing jobs, I put it to honourable senators that builders should not find themselves in this position. A proper building program should have been set up well in advance. If the ACT community accepted that the inner city development should proceed, it would receive a full measure of capital sum and annual rating financial benefits from the disposal of the section 19 site to private development interests without building a casino. This should be a matter of sensible town planning.

There is a strong argument that the National Museum would be at least as financially beneficial to the people of the ACT from the tourist point of view as a casino. While no vast sums of money would cross the museum tables, a venue of this sort would certainly persuade tourists to spend more time in Canberra. It would represent a gain in real terms for the whole of the hospitality infrastructure.

While the social impact study set up by the Minister was instructed not to consider the economic aspects of the casino proposal, the study team made extensive use of the Jebb report regarding the supply of hotel accommodation in the context of the hotel-casino complex. However, I note that the Canberra Accommodation Industry Association submission argued strongly against increased up-market hotel accommodation for Canberra as the industry has reported poor occupancy figures as part of a consistent trend. In fact, the current trend is towards comfortable but economic hotels such as the new Greetings chain.

I have briefly looked at some of the economic proposals for the casino, but I did this with some reluctance not because I am not concerned about the economic impact or the need for any major projects for Canberra, but because I believe that it is not what this particular argument should be based on. Presumably, jobs would be provided now and in the future if we built a smelter, a brothel or a power station on section 19. However, that would be an inappropriate use of a main section of the nation's capital. It would be an inappropriate use of this section of lands which is situated at one of the vertices of the Parliamentary Triangle. I put it to honourable senators that a casino is equally inappropriate, especially in that central area of our capital.

Various Ministers have argued at various times during this debate that gambling is a part of the fabric of Australian society and that, therefore, a casino would make no substantial difference. But I guess that brothels, pornography, and drugs and alcohol, unfortunately, are also part of the fabric of Australian society. If a glass of wine with dinner does no harm, do we encourage wholesale boozing? No. We do not go along that path. We do not offer the easy means to massive addiction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not very convincing, Senator.

—I am afraid that I regard that as a valid argument. In many ways Canberra is a beautiful city. It is spacious and clean and its architecture ranges from monumental, to cosy suburban, to post-modern brutalism in some of the office buildings. The town plan evolved into a cluster of discrete communities, each with its own character and each with its own community feeling. I must say, as a Western Australian, that I admire the sense of purpose and community spirit which typifies Canberra and I contrast the concrete jungle which is central Perth with the clean squares of Civic, with its original human scale buildings still intact.

SPEECH.PARA: But Canberra, say the critics, is dull: there is no soul and no night life. I suspect that this criticism is largely made by outsiders. I add that Canberra seems to me to lack something of the vibrant 24-hour-a-day activity of, say, Carlton in Melbourne, or Fremantle or North Perth in Western Australia. But night life in these places is characterised by a multiplicity of many small restaurants, coffee houses, pubs and theatres. There is a sense of metropolitan style and a great awareness of one's neighbours. So I doubt very much whether a casino would contribute to night life, other than within its own doors.

It is remarkable how the advertising image of casinos differs from reality. I make no claim to an encyclopaedic knowledge of casinos, but I and my staff have visited casinos both in Australia and overseas and, typically, the advertising depicts a happy crowd of people having a good time and winning lots of money. But in fact a casino is a machine which is designed to make money out of people's pockets as rapidly as possible, otherwise there would be a great loss to the casino itself; and I can assure honourable senators that it is not there to lose money.

A casino is an unusual form of business in that it creates nothing and has no product. It really does not even provide entertainment, except as a peripheral attraction to entice customers through its doors. Documentation from Queensland suggests an almost dickensian reality of broken families, abandoned children and penniless holidaymakers appealing to overstrained welfare organisations. Experience from Perth suggests that the single type of small business which prospers in the vicinity of the casino is the pawn broker, and so many of those have grown up in the vicinity of the Burswood Island Casino in Perth. They are flourishing, with expensive television adverts and a fine selection of goods.
The previous Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, established a social impact study for the proposed casino, but this was not intended to examine the option of a casino. He said:

That's real dollars, it's jobs, it's security, it's private enterprise for Canberra and, as I've said, we're determined it's going to go ahead. The idea of the social impact study is quite simply to stop any of the potentially bad aspects of it from starting up.

In other words, as far as the Minister was concerned, the casino was a fait accompli. How does the Minister anticipate that the potentially bad aspects of a casino will be eliminated? Unlike compulsive alcohol or drug abuse, compulsive gambling is easily concealed until there is some sort of crisis. The social impact study noted that it was therefore exceedingly difficult to determine the number of excessive gamblers betting on the poker machines, at the Totalisator Agency Board and other gambling facilities here in Canberra. The number is estimated, by extrapolation from membership of Gamblers Anonymous, to be anything from 752 to 5,000. Gamblers Anonymous further states that each excessive gambler causes significant harm to 10 other people in his or her life. Honourable senators may have read a letter from E. F. Frohlich of the Society of St Vincent de Paul written to the Canberra Times and published on 26 September. In this letter he quoted from the senior social worker of Lifeline, Gold Coast, Queensland:
Our workload has increased about 10 per cent that we are aware of, due to the casino's operation . . .

Our increased workload is in the form of both individual and marital counselling related to gambling and welfare-assistance requests. The really noticeable aspect of casino gambling versus other forms of gambling is the very large amounts of money lost, including total losses of all savings and even assets.

. . . We have counselled many people who have lost their homes, businesses and marriages since the opening of the casino. More often, people will be currently struggling with a gambling habit they've created since the casino opened and which now impacts adversely on their marriage and family life and their standard of living.

Despite these limitations to our knowledge, we are aware of many individual client's distress and this mixed with the massive profits being shown by the casino has to lead to a conclusion that deep and widespread personal and financial destruction is being done in our community because of a casino . . .

The social impact study received much criticism as being no more than a whitewash operation for an already firm decision. To their credit, the members of the study team were keenly aware of this. Indeed, they reportedly likened the study to condensing a three-year PhD thesis into three months. The social impact study was short of time. The members were given a very limiting brief and they were not empowered to call and cross-examine witnesses.

For the definitive view of a casino in Australia, the Victorian report of the Board of Inquiry into Casinos is outstanding. This report, which is known as the Connor report, was delivered to the Victorian Parliament in 1983. The report recommended that no casino be permitted in Victoria. In his ministerial statement, the then Attorney-General, Mr John Cain, quoted Connor's definitions of four distinct types of casinos: the maximum revenue casino, the single entertainment-convention centre casino, the resort casino and the so-called unobtrusive casino. Mr Cain was concerned that the larger casinos would be almost impossible to operate without the incursion of organised crime. I quote from the report:
(c) resort casinos should be able, with difficulty and expense and eternal vigilance, to operate free of organised crime;

While the unobtrusive casino, which is not totally irrelevant to the present debate, should have the best prospects of operating crime free, I also quote from Mr Connor's conclusions regarding the so-called resort casinos, which I believe to be the most relevant to the situation in the Australian Capital Territory:
I recommend that resort casinos not be established in Victoria for the following reasons:
(a) they would be likely to stimulate casino gambling to an unacceptable degree;
(b) there is no substantial demonstrable demand for them;
(c) it would not be possible to rule out with confidence that they would operate free of organised crime and street crime;
(d) they are not, by comparison with certain other forms of gambling, likely to be efficient producers of revenue for the State of Victoria.
I repeat that the Connor report was the result of the fullest and most exhaustive inquiry into the whole question of casinos. Mr Cain said:

Its conclusions are clear, unequivocal and strong. The Government has considered the Report and decided that no casinos will be introduced into this State. The issue of introduction of casinos into Victoria is now closed.

Both the Connor report and the much smaller ACT study looked exhaustively at the issue of organised crime and there are continuous hints and suggestions that several well-known figures, alleged to be connected with organised crime, are also connected with casinos.

Two further aspects must be noted very briefly. Canberra is the nation's capital. This not only gives the city a certain character and its town planners certain obligations, but it also determines to a large degree the demographic make-up of the city. Canberra is the city of political power and therefore it is dangerous for any additional avenue of corruption to be introduced. The impact study reported.
The political and economic stakes could be very high indeed if even one instance of criminal infiltration or political corruption occurs in Canberra.

In conclusion, the developers want a casino-but casinos do not attract tourists; casinos do not bring in significant outside money; casinos do take local money and put it in the pockets of outside operators; casinos do attract the attention of organised crime; casinos are not necessary for enlightened town planning. Do the people of the ACT want or need a casino? The answer to that is most definitely no. But, above all, a gambling casino is totally inappropriate for the beautiful city of Canberra, the capital of the Commonwealth of Australia.

AUSTRALIAN SECURITIES COMMISSION BILL 1988

The Bills which I introduce today will bring about a fundamental change in the direction of national companies and securities law in Australia. The Bills represent one of the largest legislative undertakings of any Australian Government. Before turning to the individual Bills, I propose to outline the genesis of the legislation.
Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme

The present co-operative companies and securities scheme came into being nearly 10 years ago. Even when it was put in place, the existing scheme failed to recognise the fundamental need for a national approach for companies and securities control. The need for a national scheme was recognised by the Rae Committee in 1974 which concluded that when considering the regulatory needs of the securities market, it is essential to recognise the national character of the activities being regulated. The Rae Committee specifically rejected the concept of a commission established by several governments with continuing responsibility to all the governments concerned. The period since the establishment of the co-operative scheme has been one of rapid and fundamental change in the character of the Australian financial and securities markets. Yet the scheme has failed to meet the need for a truly national approach.

The co-operative scheme was, in some respects, a product of its time. The then Federal Government was more intent on leaving State Governments with control of companies and securities within their jurisdiction than it was with meeting the needs of the wider Australian community. Our economy is national, companies operate across the country and often in the international sphere. To overlay artificial boundaries on the national economy was to do a grave disservice to the interests of Australian business and the broader community. From the outset the co-operative scheme was fundamentally flawed. The most important deficiency was that is provided a regime in which no Parliament, no Government and no Minister had responsibility and accountability for the operation of the scheme. Thus, the scheme fell short of the fundamental democratic principles which should underpin Government activity in our society.

In its operation the scheme was also deficient. It has not been able to meet the challenges of recent years when the companies and securities market has undergone major change. There has been community concern that markets have been manipulated. Where problems have occurred they have been difficult to identify and to deal with satisfactorily because of the division of responsibility between State and Federal bodies.

The performance of the co-operative scheme has been examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That Committee in its report `The Role of Parliament on the National Companies Scheme' in April 1987 concluded that the co-operative scheme had outlived its usefulness. It unanimously recommended that the Commonwealth introduce comprehensive legislation to assume responsibility for all areas covered by the existing scheme. The Committee's recommendation was founded on an opinion of Sir Maurice Byers, QC, which asserted that the Commonwealth does have the power to enact comprehensive legislation covering company law, takeovers and the securities and futures industries.

It was against this background that the Government set out to reform the co-operative scheme and provide a regime that can meet the needs of the Australian economy into the 1990's and beyond. In doing so the Government has consistently sought to meet the legitimate wishes of the business community, State Governments and other interested groups within the community. It is unfortunate that much of the criticism which has been mounted against any change in the present system, notwithstanding its self-evident defects, has arisen from State Government concerns about perceived loss of revenue. State Governments have simply refused to accept that the national interest has required a new approach and have continued to assert that new life can be put into a scheme which has been increasingly unable to meet the pressures put on it.

If Australia is to achieve its potential it must have a basic framework for its business enterprises which promotes efficiency, which represents the national and increasingly international outlook of much of our industry and which is capable of quick reaction as circumstances change. While ensuring that the interests of shareholders and the broader community are protected, the Government must also ensure that the regulatory framework is consistent with the broader international interest. The Bills which I am introducing today will be a significant step towards that result.
A National Approach

In response to the Senate Committee's report and growing community calls for action, in September last year the Attorney-General announced the Government's intention to introduce a new companies and securities scheme based solely on Commonwealth law and with effective national administrative arrangements. The Attorney-General has held extensive negotiations with representatives of State and Territory Governments, and a wide cross section of the business community in all parts of Australia and also State and Territory Public Service employee representatives. To meet concerns expressed about some aspects of the original proposals he has been prepared to make a number of significant modifications where this does not erode the Government's fundamental objectives. Within that framework the Government has made every effort to seek the co-operation of the States and the Northern Territory. The modified proposals which the Attorney-General put to the State and the Northern Territory Governments on behalf of the Commonwealth Government in April 1988 substantially addressed concerns about the viability of independent business communities in the smaller States and the Northern Territory, their access to decision-makers, the revenues of State and Territory Governments, and employment conditions of existing State and Territory employees.

Under those proposals the States would have retained a major role in companies and securities administration, through their Corporate Affairs Commissions administering the Commonwealth laws as delegates of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) and participating in an ASC management committee to supervise the operation of the scheme. It also involved the States collectively nominating 2 part-time members of the ASC (which would also have 3 full-time members). The States would have been re-imbursed all but 1/8 of the revenue collected by the Commonwealth, with that portion being retained by the Commonwealth to fund the ASC. The highest priority would be given to the establishment of a national computer system enabling access by the public to information about every company in Australia.

Although the States have so far flatly rejected all attempts by the Commonwealth to achieve a compromise, the Attorney-General has recently received a letter from one of the State Attorneys-General suggesting a special meeting of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities to again discuss the Commonwealth legislation. The Attorney-General has agreed to a meeting to be held in Sydney on 1 November 1988 to discuss the matter.
The Commonwealth Legislation

The Bills I will introduce will replace the separate State and Territory legislation of the co-operative scheme with a single regime of Commonwealth laws applicable throughout Australia. This will restore the proper relationship between legislative policy making and the Parliament and the legitimate interests of business and other community groups. The Government is responsible for this legislation and will be held accountable for its operation and for any future legislation it seeks to introduce. The legislation for the Commonwealth scheme will be contained in the following Bills:
(a) an Australian Securities Commission Bill to provide for the administrative arrangements for the new scheme;
(b) a Corporations Bill to set out the law covering the regulation of companies, takeovers, the securities industry and the futures industry;
(c) a Close Corporations Bill to provide a new simpler and more flexible form of incorporation for small business; and
(d) ancillary Bills covering the imposition of fees and levies.

The Bills, except in some key areas referred to below, generally follow the existing co-operative companies and securities legislation. In the Bills introduced by the Attorney-General into the House of Representatives in May the Government, after consultation with the business community and other interested groups, introduced a number of significant reforms in order to remove unnecessary regulation or to overcome specific problems in the existing legislation. In his second reading speech, the Attorney-General foreshadowed, and welcomed, continuing consultation with the business community up to the passage of the legislation and referred to the role of his Companies and Securities Consultative Group.

In accordance with that commitment, during the Parliamentary recess there was extensive consultation on the legislation with the business community and others. As a result of these consultations, the Bills now incorporate a number of additional improvements to the practical operation of the legislation. These improvements, which were the subject of Government amendments in the House of Representatives during committee stage on the Bills, can be generally categorised as follows:

(i) Amendments to the fund raising provisions of the Bill to clarify their operation, particularly in relation to prescribed interests, to increase protection for investors in respect of certain classes of fund raising and to identify those situations where prospectuses are not required.

(ii) Amendments to ameliorate some unintended consequences of reforms which were to clarify and rectify some technical anomalies in the takeover provisions, the securities recommendations provisions and the licensing provisions of the cooperative scheme legislation.
(iii) Amendments to clarify the role and power of the Australian Securities Commission;
(iv) Amendments to the futures industry provisions, foreshadowed at the introduction of the Bills, to minimise any disruption as a result of the constitutional underpinnings of those provisions; and
(v) Amendments, also foreshadowed at the introduction of the Bills in May, to bring court jurisdiction, administrative and judicial review under the Bills into conformity with Commonwealth practice.
These changes and the earlier reforms are set out in more detail below and in the second reading speeches on the Corporations Bill and the Close Corporations Bill.

Many changes of form from the existing legislation derive from the need to express the Bills in language reflecting Commonwealth institutional powers and to reflect their character as truly national legislation. Although principally based on the Commonwealth's constitutional power over trading and financial corporations, a wide range of other supporting constitutional powers have been relied on where appropriate. These include the powers in respect of interstate trade and commerce, posts and telecommunications, banking and insurance, and cheques and negotiable instruments. The opportunity has also been taken to rationalise the structure of the legislation and to correct some minor anomalies.
Consultation

The Bills introduced by the Attorney-General in May reflected considerable input from the business community and other interests. In particular, members of the Companies and Securities Consultative Group made many useful recommendations which were adopted in the original legislation. The Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives on the basis that they would lie on the table over the winter recess to allow an opportunity for public exposure and further examination of the Bills. As indicated above, in his second reading speech on this Bill in the House of Representatives the Attorney-General foreshadowed continuing consultation with interested groups during the Parliamentary recess.

Many business organisations, such as the Australian Stock Exchange and the Sydney Futures Exchange have made submissions on or discussed the legislation with the Attorney-General. The Consultative Group called for and received public submissions. It has carried out a detailed examination of the legislation and the concerns raised by business organisations and professionals such as the exchanges, the Unit Trust Association, the Company Directors' Association and the Institute of Directors. Following this the Group has made many useful recommendations most of which have been adopted in the amendments I have referred to. The Government would like to again record its appreciation for the voluntary work of the Group.

The overall response of the business community has been very supportive of the legislation. In particular the national small business Organisations, such as the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia and the Australian Small Business Association have strongly supported the Close Corporations Bill.
The Australian Securities Commission Bill 1988

The Australian Securities Commission Bill 1988 (ASC Bill) establishes the major administrative organs of the new national scheme. The first among these is the new Australian Securities Commission which will replace the NCSC and will be responsible for the administration of the scheme. The powers given to the ASC will ensure that it is able to be a strong and effective regulatory body, yet one which is flexible and responsive to developments in the market place. The ASC Bill also specifically recognises the role of the ASC in the formulation of legislative policy.

The ASC Bill clarifies the relationship between the ASC and this Parliament. In the Westminster tradition the ASC will be solely responsible to the Commonwealth Minister and through him or her to Parliament. The independence of the ASC is made clear in that the Bill does not permit the Minister to give directions on specific matters. In the interests of accountability, this is balanced by enabling the Minister to give directions as to general policies or priorities, which must both be written and made public. By contrast, the NCSC may be subject to a direction by the Ministerial Council on any matter, whether specific or general, and the direction need not be publicised.

As a measure of the importance which the Government attaches to community participation in the development of business regulation, the ASC Bill will establish a new statutory consultative body, the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee. The Committee will be composed of a broad spectrum of community interests-business, market participants, company administrators, investors, professional advisers and other interested groups. It is important that all parts of Australia are adequately represented on this Committee. The role of the Committee will be to advise the Minister on the legislation and administration of the national scheme and to keep the Minister informed of new developments in the markets that may require action. So as to ensure that the Advisory Committee is able to perform its functions effectively, the Bill provides for separate funding, staffing and research facilities for the Committee.

The ASC Bill contains provisions which give strengthened inspection and investigation powers to the ASC compared with those of the NCSC and clarify the scope of the hearings powers. The separate inspection and special investigation powers of the existing legislation will be amalgamated to make the operation of investigations more effective. An amendment has been incorporated into the Bill to put beyond doubt the power of the ASC to investigate a matter for the purpose of bringing a case before the Panel. In addition a further amendment has been made so that it is clear that the ASC's ability to begin a prosecution does not override the role of the Director of Public Prosecutions. The Bill authorises the ASC to disclose information to overseas agencies performing comparable functions. An amendment was made by the Government to widen the provisions and authorise the ASC to disclose information to a domestic or overseas agency for the purpose of the performance of that agency's functions. This will facilitate mutual co-operation with overseas law enforcement agencies and local bodies such as the Australian Stock Exchange and Sydney Futures Exchange in enforcing compliance with their rules. The opportunity for harmonising companies and securities laws and administrative arrangements will be greatly enhanced by ensuring that ultimate responsibility rests with one Australian Government rather than eight. In this context I note that on 1 July 1988 the Australian and New Zealand Governments entered into a Memorandum of Understanding to examine the harmonisation of their respective companies and securities laws and other business laws.

A major new feature of the legislation is the establishment of the Corporations and Securities Panel on the recommendation of the Consultative Group. It is considered inappropriate for the regulatory authority, which has a legitimate charter to investigate malpractices in the market place, to also perform ajudicatory functions in relation to those malpractices. The Panel will perform those ajudicatory functions. The Panel will, initially, be conferred with power to declare acquisitions of shares or conduct in relation to a takeover unacceptable. It will be required to hold a hearing before making such a declaration. The requirement that all Panel hearings be held in private was amended so that the Panel may decide to hold a hearing in public if all parties so agree. The Panel will have powers to issue restraining or remedial orders which were previously exercised by the Courts. Decisions of the Panel will be final, subject of course, to appeals on questions of law. It is envisaged that, in the future, further functions will be conferred on the Panel when it is sufficiently established to conduct a larger number of ajudicative hearings.

In view of the role of the Corporations and Securities Panel to conduct hearings, and the expanded investigations powers of the ASC, the ASC's function to conduct hearings has been narrowed. It is limited to two main situations-to afford natural justice to a person whose licence or registration it proposes to revoke and to hold public hearings to ascertain views on the exercise by the ASC of its administrative responsibilities (e.g. a proposed policy statement or guideline). In order to enable the ASC to maintain complete national registers for the benefit of the public and to obviate any need for documents lodged under the previous legislation to be relodged by companies, the ASC will be empowered to acquire records kept by State and Territory Corporate Affairs Commissions, in the event that they are not voluntarily provided.

A separate disciplinary body, the Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board which presently exists separately in most States and Territories, will now be constituted as a single entity in the ASC Bill. The Bill also re-creates, in statutory form, the current Accounting Standards Review Board.

To ensure proper Parliamentary accountability an amendment has been incorporated into the Bill requiring the Corporations and Securities Panel, the Advisory Committee and the Companies' Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board along with other bodies established under the Bill to prepare annual reports to be tabled in Parliament.

In relation to judicial review of the actions of the ASC, the Bills now provide for full merits review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and judicial review by the Federal Court. This accords with the view of the ARC and will permit de novo review of administrative decisions within the constitutional constraints of judicial power.

Jurisdiction to hear civil cases under the scheme will continue to be vested concurrently in the State and Territory Supreme Courts and the Federal Court. However, the Bill has been amended so that, in accordance with normal Commonwealth practice, State Supreme Courts will now have exclusive jurisdiction in criminal matters. Amendments introduced by the Attorney-General will also provide for the State and Territory Supreme Court jurisdiction to be exercised by a single judge and for appeals to lie as of right to the Federal Court and by leave to the High Court.

CORPORATIONS BILL 1988

The Corporations Bill heralds a new direction in national companies and securities law and administration. If Australian business enterprises and markets are to remain competitive in the new national and international trading environment, it is essential to have national legislation which provides a flexible and responsive regulatory environment in which companies can operate efficiently. The Corporations Bill provides this national legislation. This Bill amalgamates into one law the areas presently covered by the separate co-operative scheme codes, namely the Companies Code, the Acquisition of Shares Code, the Securities Industry Code and the Futures Industry Code. Apart form those key areas outlined below, in which reforms have been undertaken to deal with specific problems or regulatory burdens which have been widely acknowledged under present law, the Corporations Bill generally re-enacts the existing legal requirements. The Government's approach has been that it would not be appropriate for the introduction of national legislation to be accompanied by more extensive changes to the fundamental structure of the existing law than has been attempted in this Bill without further consultation with interested sectors of the community.

The Bill is, for the most part, the same as the one introduced by the Attorney-General in the House of Representatives on 25 May 1988. However, as I indicated in the second reading speech on the Australian Securities Commission Bill, the opportunity has been taken to incorporate a number of significant improvements to the practical operation of the legislation which resulted from the extensive process of consultation engaged in by the Attorney-General while the Bill lay on the table over the winter recess.
Structure and Style of Legislation

The consolidation of the existing law into the Corporations Bill and the Australian Securities Commission Bill has led to the removal of much duplicated material and to a major rationalisation of the structure and arrangement of the legislation. The definitions and interpretation provisions for the Bill have largely been incorporated into one Interpretation Chapter. The next 5 Chapters generally conform to the structure of the existing Companies Code. Other Chapters, such as the Acquisition of Shares, the Securities Industry and the Futures Industry Chapters essentially cover the same ground as the corresponding Codes under the existing law. There has also been a re-organisation of material across chapters: for example, the provisions dealing with prospectuses and the transfer of marketable securities have been moved from the Companies related chapters to the Securities Chapter where they more properly belong. In addition, large groupings of sections have, wherever possible, been broken up into smaller groupings, and long sections and sub-sections split into shorter ones, thus allowing a much greater use of Part, Division and Section headings. These hearings will help the reader to find the provisions of concern to him or her and make them easier to follow.

The existing law has, in some important areas, been reworked to give it clarity and simplicity. These include, in particular, the parts of the Corporations Bill that deal with financial statements of companies, names of corporations, registration of foreign companies, and the transfer of marketable securities.

The chapter dealing with the Acquisition of Shares adopts a number of the structural improvements suggested by the Victorian Law Reform Commission in its final report on ``Plain English and the Law''. However, the essential language and concepts of the previous law remain, in order to accurately reflect the existing law as currently understood by market participants.
Major Reforms

In the drafting of the national law, the opportunity has been taken to introduce a number of substantial reforms in areas of the law that have been bedevilling the business community because of the excessive and unnecessary regulation imposed. These reforms, incorporating the amendments moved in the House of Representatives during the committee stage, reflect substantial input from the business community and the considered recommendations of the Companies and Securities Consultative Group after detailed examination of submissions on the Bills from business organisations and professionals, generally. Some of the main reform proposals are as follows. The fund-raising provisions of the legislation will be substantially simplified and new provisions introduced to shift the thrust of the fund-raising controls from the regulatory authority to the market. Thus, to ensure that fund-raising activities are not impeded by delays or the imposition of unnecessary costs by the regulatory authority, the ASC will no longer pre-vet all prospectuses. To provide additional protection to the general public in respect of primary offerings by unlisted companies, about which investors will have insufficient prior information, the Bill now incorporates an amendment requiring prospectuses of that type to be pre-vetted. At the same time, in response to public submissions, the Bill has been amended to specify a wider range of circumstances in which a prospectus is not required, such as, for small capital raisings of offers of an essentially `private' character. Because they are subject to informed market scrutiny, Part A statements, profit forecasts and asset valuations during a takeover will not be pre-vetted. As well, the complex and detailed rules as to the content of prospectuses will be replaced by much more basic disclosure rules designed to provide investors with the relevant information they need to make informed investment decisions. The Bill makes it clear that different levels of disclosure may be appropriate depending on the type of offer, e.g. whether it is a rights issue to existing members or an offer to the public at large.

Obligations will be imposed on those engaged in fund-raising to promote self-enforcement by the market. There will be a general prohibition on misleading or deceptive conduct in relation to the issue of or trading in securities-based on section 52 of the Trade Practices Act 1974. To maintain appropriate safeguards for investor protection the ASC will be able to issue orders to stop serious misrepresentation or malpractice and investors will have an enhanced range of remedies enabling them to take action against a wider class of persons involved in the preparation of the prospectus. However, in response to recommendations of the Consultative Group, the provisions imposing liability on advisers have been modified in the present Bill so that the liability will be more closely related to the functions performed by the adviser in relation to the prospectus.

The procedure provided by section 261 of the Companies Act, which enables a company to trace beneficial ownership of its shares, imposes a costly paper burden on the market as a whole and has been abused. The Bill removes the scope for this abuse. Only the ASC will have power to obtain information as to beneficial ownership. However, in order to maintain appropriate levels of shareholder disclosure, the substantial shareholding reporting requirements have been reduced from 10% to 5%.

The procedure for registering company names has been simplified. The provisions establishing the present ``subjective test'' on whether a name is available for reservation have been removed. All company names will be allowed, except for identical names and names of a type to be prescribed in Regulations such as names suggesting connection with the Government. The Bill also clarifies that companies are permitted to incorporate with number names to facilitate faster incorporations.

To assist in the development of a more efficient securities market, provisions have been included to remove delays in the transfer and registration of securities occasioned by unnecessary forms. The requirement that a transferor sign a transfer form has been removed. However, full compensation will be available from the National Guarantee Fund, provided for under this Bill, for any losses arising from unauthorised transfers. Transferee acceptance forms will also be deleted. There will no longer be a requirement that companies maintain branch registers at a shareholder's request. This will save costs for the several parties involved in processing certificates and transfers and will simplify the operation of the proposed new transfer and settlement system currently being developed by the Australian Stock Exchange.

It is proposed to discontinue the licensing of representatives of securities dealers and advisers and of futures brokers and advisers. To ensure that proper responsibility is taken for the activities of their representatives, the principals will be fully liable for the conduct persons who are, in fact, their representatives. Amendments were incorporated into the Bill in the House of Representatives to clarify the scope of this liability.

In addition, the Bill has been amended to remove undesirable burdens on the operation of the securities industry which may have resulted from certain requirements of the Bill as introduced in the House of Representatives. In particular I mention that the Bill now specifically recognises the creation of an effective `Chinese Wall' as a defence to a potential conflict of interest situation. The Bill also omits the unworkable requirement that advisers provide subsequent written confirmation of every oral disclosure of an interest in a recommendation made to a client.

As foreshadowed by the Attorney-General when introducing the Bill in May, amendments to the futures industry provisions have been incorporated in the Bill following extensive consultations with the Sydney Futures Exchange. These amendments include the more extensive use of constitutional powers to prohibit unauthorised futures markets, or so called `bucket shops', from harming investors. Other amendments have been made to facilitate the effective operation of the futures exchange, such as widening the membership of the exchange to include unincorporated persons dealing on their own account to add greater depth and liquidity to the market.

In the light of the abolition of the doctrine of ultra vires and rules of constructive notice affecting outsiders, proprietary companies will be relieved of the obligation to lodge a copy of their memorandum and articles of association with the ASC upon their incorporation. This reform will reduce administrative costs for the ASC.

In making these changes to the existing legislative controls, the Government has sought to create a more efficient commercial environment by reducing unnecessary and costly regulatory burdens while ensuring adequate protections remain for both shareholders and other investors and providing a framework for the fair and honest operation of the market.

CLOSE CORPORATIONS BILL 1988

The purpose of the Close Corporations Bill 1988 is to provide a new simplified corporate structure for small business. Many of the current detailed rules applying to companies that are more appropriate for larger companies impose inflexible requirements and costly and unnecessary burdens on small companies. The distinctive features of the new corporate form which will enhance flexibility and reduce operating costs involve the reduction in financial and other reporting requirements and replacing the usual concept of management with simpler association rules. Details of the provisions are set out in the explanatory memorandum that is circulated with the Bill.

Memorandum and articles of association will not be required and will be replaced by a non-registrable written association agreement. This enables the formal shareholder/director distinction to be eliminated and will allow the internal affairs of the corporation to be governed by simpler partnership rules. An optional model association agreement will be prescribed in the regulations.

Basic information about the close corporation will be filed in the form of a Founding Statement which will be updated each time there is a change to the material particulars. A Certificate of compliance will be an annual document in which the close corporation states that accounts have been kept which accurately reflect the financial position of the Corporation. The Close Corporation Bill provides a simple means for small business to obtain the benefits of incorporation such as limited liability. However, under the Bill the interests of creditors are also safeguarded by a number of provisions which enable the corporate veil to be lifted and personal liability to attach to the members. Thus, members may be personally liable for a debt incurred by the close corporation:
where accounts have not been properly kept;
if the close corporation becomes a holding company and subsequently becomes insolvent; or
where there is unreasonable delay in taking action where the corporation is insolvent.

The Bill permits a close corporation to acquire the shares of members in certain circumstances including, where the members have signed a declaration of solvency. Personal liability will attach to the signatories of that declaration where, subsequently, the corporation commences to be wound up and will attach to members where the close corporation has unlawfully acquired its own shares. The Bill is a major innovation in corporation law to meet longstanding needs of small business for an uncomplicated business structure.

Consequential amendments were made to the Bill in the House of Representatives to bring the Bill into line with corresponding amendments made to the ASC Bill and Corporations Bill concerning such matters as administrative review and court jurisdiction. I have addressed the effect of these amendments in the second reading speeches on those Bills.
