SPEECH.PARA: That, acknowledging that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has unanimously recommended that the Commonwealth should introduce comprehensive legislation to assume responsibility for all areas covered by the co-operative scheme and that a package of Bills for this purpose is now before the Senate, the Bills be referred to a select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, and the Committee inquire into and report on the Bills for the regulation of companies and the securities and futures industries with reference only to the adequacy of the proposed legislative provisions to:
(a) improve the regulation of companies;
(b) facilitate the performance of the securities and futures markets; and
(c) ensure adequate protection for investors in companies and the securities and futures markets;
and, in particular, report on the adequacy of the fund-raising provisions.
(2) That the Committee consist of 10 members, as follows:
(a) 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate,
(b) 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate,
(c) 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats,
(d) 3 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by or on behalf of the Prime Minister, and
(e) 2 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition.
(3) That the Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by or on behalf of the Prime Minister or by the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That the quorum of the Committee be 5 members.

(8) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, and the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(9) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be all the members appointed to the sub-committee.

(10) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That the Committee report to each House of the Parliament by the first day of sitting of that House in 1989.

(13) That the Committee have access to any relevant evidence and records of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.
(14) The the Committee cease upon the dissolution or expiration of the House of Representatives.
(15) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.
(16) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution be communicated by message to the House of Representative with a request for the concurrence of that House in the Resolution.
(17) That consideration of the motion for the second reading of the Bills be an Order of the Day for the day on which the Committee reports to the Senate.
I draw honourable senators' attention to paragraph (12), which seeks a reporting date on the first sitting day of the House in 1989, and to paragraph (13), which states:

That the Committee have access to any relevant evidence and records of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

The latter paragraph is important because, as honourable senators well know, our own Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has for some time been dealing with the issue of the obligations of company directors, and the corresponding Committee in the House of Representatives has been dealing with the very vexed issue of company takeovers. Both issues are dealt with to some extent in this package of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Are these Bills laid on the table? Are they physically present in the chamber?
—I believe they are, yes. Do you wish to have copies of them?
—Yes.

—Mr President, as you said, in formally receiving the message from the House of Representatives, the package of Bills we are dealing with, and indeed the Corporations Bill 1988, is of such size that it is the largest piece of legislation ever introduced into the Federal Parliament. These Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives on 25 May and after a couple of weeks I did toy with the idea of suggesting to the Senate that only those members who had read the Bills should be allowed to debate them, on the grounds that we may have a very short debate indeed.
—That's not a bad idea.

—I am glad Senator Messner thinks it is an excellent idea. It is a fascinating collection of Bills. I recommend that honourable senators read them because, for the first time, we have brought together from some 50 disparate pieces of legislation the totality of the regulations and legislation governing the operation of companies in Australia. That is a massive task, as the size of the Bills indicates. Not only have they been consolidated in these Bills but there have also been some quite radical proposals included.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government quite rightly has had in operation for quite some time a consultative mechanism. Those honourable senators who have been following this particular procedure will know that parts of that consultative mechanism have worked very well: other parts, unfortunately, have not. Probably the most outstanding feature of the consultative mechanism is the extraordinarily small number of submissions that have been made. One would believe that in an area as important as this, as comprehensive as this, and as far reaching as this, there would be a number of submissions that would overwhelm the consultative committee. But this was not so. When one looks through the submissions one sees that very few of them go beyond one page and that most of them are mere expressions of opinions or points of view and do not really go into a great deal of detail. If honourable members had been seeking details on these issues they would have had to talk to people in the industry. I am sure that a large number of members of both the Government and the Opposition have been doing so. Quite a number of people in the industry are willing to give of their time and energy-they have done so with me-for days working through a whole variety of these items. It is not as though there is a lack of interest, a lack of informed opinion, a lack of detailed points of view out there, but for whatever reason that has not come through the consultative mechanism.

In my consideration of these Bills it slowly became apparent that a further mechanism needed to be provided before they became law. I believe that it is a legitimate exercise of this chamber, and I hope of the House of Representatives if it concurs with this reference, to set up a joint committee, comprising senators and members who are interested in these areas, to be available to people in the community who wish to make submissions that for one reason or another were not made to the consultative committee or were made but were felt by those submitting them not to have been dealt with in as sympathetic or as adequate a way as they would have liked, or those who now have had the time to work through these Bills. I remind honourable senators that these Bills have been available since 25 May. In recent weeks it has become apparent that a number of organisations have at last managed to get on top of these Bills and have formulated their views. That length of time is not unusual, given that most of the associations one is dealing with are constituted on a State basis and would need to come together on a national basis to consolidate their particular submissions.

It is also apparent that quite a number of organisations and associations have views that differ from State to State. For example, it is obvious that the stance taken by a couple of major organisations in my own State of Queensland and in Western Australia differs quite significantly from the stance taken by their colleagues in Victoria and New South Wales. That is to be expected, particularly since, one would assume, the new Securities Commission will be based in Melbourne. There is a significant difference, particularly for the small companies-what are called in this package of legislation `close corporations'- between being able to get to headquarters if one happens to be resident in Sydney or Melbourne and bringing someone across from Perth or down from Brisbane. The larger companies, of course, do not have that problem. The cost of lodging a Queen's Counsel in Melbourne for three or four days would not be noticed in their budgetary arrangements. For small companies to do so would not only eat up their profits for a year but probably bankrupt most of them. Hence there is an enormous range of views that have to be considered when one is dealing with companies in Australia.

We have had to date a cooperative scheme that has had its problems, but I think it has probably had a worse press than it really deserves. It has marked up a significant number of important positions to its credit. Obviously in looking ahead we can see that there will be significant changes within the Australian community and the international trading community, of which we have to be a part. It is our view as a party that the significant changes that we see coming will have to be dealt with at a national level. Hence we have indicated from the very start that we are supportive of the notion and the position that was taken by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that there should be a comprehensive national scheme. We have felt that to date there really has been a singular lack of parliamentary control of legislation.

The cooperative scheme essentially was controlled by executives. Those members here who dealt with the various pieces of legislation that came through under that cooperative scheme will remember the debates that we have had-I was here for some debates when the Fraser Government was in office-have expressed their concern. We felt constrained at not being able to amend the legislation and there were parts that we wished to amend but, considering the difficulty of getting all the executive governments within Australia to agree on anything, the Senate felt constrained not to amend the legislation in case it jettisoned the reforms that were obviously desirable in totality, although it may have disagreed with particular items.

It is for that reason that I sought a meeting with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). On 29 July I met the Attorney in Sydney and proposed to him that when the Bills came into the Senate I would move for the appointment of a joint select committee to look at the legislation. I put to him that I felt that such a committee could provide industry with another avenue before the enactment of the legislation to go into technical details and look, for example, at the issue that had not then been altered by the Government-the items of pre-vetting. The Government has introduced amendments on pre-vetting that go a significant way to meeting the concerns that have been expressed in the community. But the secondary market probably has not been touched although a great deal of concern was also expressed in that area.

The Government has, through its consultative committee, sought to respond in a fairly comprehensive way to many of the concerns in the community. Although the Attorney-General at that stage indicated to me that he intended to do that, I persisted with the proposition that a joint committee be appointed. I felt that it would be of advantage for a number of reasons. First of all, my Party has been supportive of the moves that have been made in recent years for the establishment of statutory committees. Two new statutory committees are now operating, after the Joint Committee on Public Works, which is the oldest of our statutory committees. They are the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority and the Joint Statutory Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization. But in terms of the developing expertise that will be required within the parliamentary structure to deal with these matters, I felt that the proposed committee might be the forerunner of a statutory committee that would have as its task the oversight of all this legislation.

That suggestion has another political angle to it. It has been felt that the establishment of a single legislative base could open up business legislation to greater political interference. It is proposed in the legislation that a new body, an independent commission, will replace the existing National Companies and Securities Commission. I think in reality the National Companies and Securities Commission has operated very freely. The only body which can control the Commission is the body which consists of Ministers from all of the executive governments. However, it has found it very difficult to control the Commission and, hence, the Commission has been independent. I think that independence has been appreciated by the business community, which wants it retained. So there has been some concern that obviously there is the potential for the opening up of greater political interference if there is consolidation under one government.

I think a parliamentary committee with oversight would remove that worry. Members of such a committee would have the opportunity to apprise themselves of the way in which the legislation operates. I am mindful of the fact that I had the good fortune to serve on the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. That Committee recommended to the Parliament-and our recommendation was accepted-a comprehensive list of reforms to our electoral laws. That Committee was retained by the Parliament to review the operation of those laws in the practicality of an election context. As honourable senators well know, that review led to well over 100 further amendments, some of which related to changes we had made before because in practical terms, it was felt that they were too complex or that they did not have the desired effect. Quite frankly, I felt that the exercise, in terms of my work as a legislator, was one of the most satisfying that I have done. It gave me a chance to be involved in making recommendations, to see them enacted, to review them in action, and then to change the law again in the light of practice. Obviously these Bills will be amended over time. Undoubtedly various unintended consequences will emerge. A Senate committee inquiry would enable us to make sure that the possibilities of unintended consequences is reduced to an absolute minimum.

The other angle, the policy item, was discussed at the meeting that I had with the Attorney-General on 29 July. I indicated to him that we would be unwilling to have an inquiry which opened up that policy item. I think there are a number of reasons for this. One is that, if the policy item were opened up, the possibility of seeing an end to the debate in the committee would be relatively slim. Given the lines which have already been drawn in the political context between the positions of the various parties on this matter, I think one would probably be able to predict that at least a couple of reports would come from such a committee at the end of the exercise.

That really was not my major concern. My major concern was that till now there seems to have been, as I have already indicated, very little by way of input to these Bills from industry and business through the consultative process. It struck me that that may very well stem from the not unexceptional sort of assumption that these Bills might not get enacted. The thought that we could go through a whole exercise and again have little input from business on the technicalities of the Bills was of enormous concern. We have to improve a number of areas and we need to have a detailed input from industry. So I felt that an inquiry specifically targeted to the technicalities of the Bills before the chamber was the appropriate type of inquiry to pursue. Fairly obviously it is not the only type, and I understand that Senator Hill, on behalf of the Opposition, will be seeking to amend the proposal by suggesting alternative terms of reference.

However, the type of inquiry I am suggesting is appropriate is one that will actually focus on the legislation itself rather than on the broader and legitimate differences between the political parties. Undoubtedly those differences will be debated again in this chamber in the Committee of the Whole stage of the 16 Bills, and if past committee stages on Bills of this size are anything to go by, that is likely to be an extensive debate. That is legitimate. But, as I said to the Attorney, the inquiry I was suggesting was not meant in any shape or form to be part of a delaying tactic. It was meant as a contribution to the legislative process and as a testing, in some ways, of the types of things that another committee of which I am a member is trying to come to grips with-that is, how we can improve our activities as a chamber dedicated to the scrutiny of legislation. The proposals put forward by the Opposition in Senator Chaney's comprehensive motion concerning committee inquiries have been subject to some discussion in that committee, and there has also been discussion within the party rooms, as to how we might move down that track. As has been suggested on all sides, that will require a fair amount of trust and that would be witness to the fact that this chamber is serious about its task of scrutinising legislation.

Undoubtedly in the past some committees have had more than an inquiry on their minds, and we will probably have the same thing at some stage in the future. But that was not what my suggestion to the Attorney was about. This committee should have the chance to visit every capital city, to meet with those people who undoubtedly want to have an input, and to concentrate-as the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform was able to do-on the very text of the Bills before us. The committee could then report back to the chamber, hopefully with detailed suggestions for amendments that have flowed through from the inquiry. Our deliberations here in the Committee of the Whole would then be that much better informed as a result of members of all political parties having been exposed to that process. It is for that reason that I have moved the motion circulated.

It is suggested that the committee have a membership of 10. That would provide the opportunity for representation from all parties in each of the chambers. As is normal, the committee would be chaired by a member of the Government. The only point which differs from normal is the item to which I have already drawn attention, and that is the ability, if agreed to by the House of Representatives, of this committee to have access to the material currently held by both the Senate and the House standing committees dealing with matters pertinent to this legislation.

I hope that the proposal will receive the support of the chamber, that the committee will be set up as soon as possible, and that we can show that our committee inquiries can be dealt with expeditiously and in a way which does not delay legislation, which is, in fact, a constituent part of what this chamber should be about; that is, the detailed scrutiny of the legislation that is placed before it by the other chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is also of the view that the Bills should be referred to a joint committee for consideration. However, we differ from the Australian Democrats, who have proposed to the Senate a narrow committee reference, described by Senator Macklin this morning as `an examination of the technicalities of the Bills'. We believe that there are much wider and more fundamental questions to be determined by the Senate before the second reading debate proceeds. Therefore, we seek to amend the Democrats' motion and insert much wider terms of reference. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out paragraph (1), insert:

``(1) That the Bills be referred to a select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, and the Committee examine the Bills for unintended legal and commercial consequences, and report whether:
(a) the Bills and the scheme thereby created meet the legitimate needs of the business community, all State Governments and other interested groups within the community;

(b) passage of the Bills and the scheme thereby created is the only means of facilitating further national and international development of Australian business, or whether a modified cooperative scheme could achieve such objectives, and in particular whether a transfer to the Commonwealth of takeover and associated securities provisions could achieve the Government's stated objectives;
(c) an efficient regulatory system can be achieved by an alternative scheme other than that proposed by the Bills, i.e., the complete centralisation of power;
(d) the interests of shareholders and the broader investor community are adequately protected by the Bills;
(e) it is desirable and advisable to proceed with passage of the Bills considering the serious constitutional concerns which have been raised regarding their validity; and
(f) passage of the Bills will result in:
(i) the loss by the State regulatory authorities and their respective business communities of accessibility and the ability to influence policy and law-making;
(ii) additional costs to business;
(iii) a loss of skilled staff from State corporate affairs offices;
(iv) loss of business and professional expertise in the States as a result of the transfer of power from the States to the Federal Government; and
(v) adequate funding and resources to ensure that the regulatory system can function efficiently and react promptly to immediate concerns.''

We propose this much wider examination because, although I am not prone to the use of extravagant language, I have to say that what the Government is seeking to do with this package of Bills is little short of disgraceful. I say that because the Government knows that the Bills will not become law. In the recent debate in the House of Representatives the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) indicated that he had agreed to go back to the Attorneys-General of the States to discuss the matter further. He has agreed to do that because none of the States is supportive of these very fundamental changes which he is seeking to make to corporate law in this country. We know that some of the States are now talking about the prospect of an alternative split scheme. That is likely to be what the Attorney-General will accept. So we have the Bills introduced into the Senate for debate-some 16 Bills comprising 3,000 pages and over 1,300 clauses-in circumstances where the Attorney-General and the Government know that they will not become law; some alternative scheme is much more likely to be proposed to the Senate. Therefore we ask: What is the point in setting up a Senate inquiry to investigate the technicalities of these Bills if even the Government acknowledges that much more fundamental questions have yet to be determined?

We say further that the Bills should not be dealt with in this way because of the very dubious constitutional validity of the package, and I will expand upon that in a moment. We certainly say that, again, there is no point in simply looking at the technicalities of the Bills if there is a very grave doubt that the package as a whole would stand up constitutionally. It would be much more worthwhile, we would suggest, if the joint committee examined that question of constitutionality, as well as the question of the potential for a split scheme, with part of the package going to the Commonwealth.

We believe that a wide-ranging inquiry is more appropriate because of the enormously broad based opposition of business and professional groups throughout this country to the package as presented by the Government. I have never come across such a situation: I think all professional bodies in the fields of law, accounting and business are opposed to this package of Bills and nearly every business organisation in the country is likewise opposed. There are fundamental questions that the joint committee should look at that come out of those expressed concerns, not just at questions of detail. As I have said, we also believe that a broad-ranging inquiry is warranted by the fact that all the States, including Labor governed States, are opposed to the scheme. In a federal system, if all the States are opposed to it, it makes this transfer of power unworkable in practice. Perhaps a joint committee of the Parliament could help where this Government seems to have failed; that is, by looking at whether there is some compromise that could win support from all the States.

We are further opposed to this narrow ranged inquiry as such because of what the Government has referred to as its consultative process with business and professions which involved the setting up of committees, consultative groups, subcommittees, steering groups and so forth. As I will indicate in a moment or two, that simply became a sham. If the Government was not prepared to enter into proper consultations, we believe that this Parliament, through a joint committee process, can do so.

We are opposed to the narrow ranged inquiry because the Bills are so fundamentally flawed that the Government introduced 280 of its own amendments into the House of Representatives before the debate proceeded. It is unprecedented in the legislative history of this country for a government to put down its Bills and then come back with 280 of its own amendments which it seeks to have passed. The amendments are so complex, so detailed and so numerous that, as I understand it, we cannot even get a proper reprint of the Bills for this debate. I suspect that that is also unprecedented.

It seems to us on this side of the chamber that it would be grossly negligent if the Senate were simply to refer the Bills to a committee to look at the technicalities of the package. Therefore we argue in the strongest possible terms that, before looking at the technicalities, the Parliament should be considering these broader, more fundamental questions. We are disappointed that the Australian Democrats do not recognise the importance of what I have just said and are not prepared to become part of a constructive overview of these fundamental questions but rather are prepared to be a part of the farce that this Government is attempting to bring to the Senate today.

I stress that what we are looking at in this enormous package of legislation is a most fundamental restructuring of Australian corporate law. It could be said that it is the most fundamental restructuring since Federation. If one accepted the notion of the cooperative scheme as an interim between total State powers and control in the area of corporate law, one would argue that it is the most fundamental restructuring since Federation. We are not dealing with Bills of little consequence; we are dealing with a package of legislation which is of very major consequence constitutionally, as well as of great consequence to business and professions in this country. We are also looking-I do not want to be too emotive-at a takeover by the Commonwealth of the right to regulate the corporate and securities industry in this country, which raises all the basic questions of federalism that should be considered by this inquiry but which will not be if the Government supports the Democrats' motion.

The content of the Bills should also be looked at. That is not in dispute as far as we are concerned. We acknowledge that it is fundamentally a new scheme. It sets up new commissions, new committees, et cetera, and creates new law. It even introduces a new language, what we call plain English, which I do not necessarily think is a bad thing, but which will mean a whole new range of precedents within corporate law-matters that should be looked at very carefully by this Parliament before they are enacted. New concepts are introduced. For example, I refer to one contained in the Australian Securities Commission Bill-that is, an obligation upon that body to strive to attend to certain matters. Notions that in the past have been unknown in our legal system will now be incorporated within the law. Perhaps the time has come for this to happen. Some of us would like to see more plain English in the taxation law. It means that we should tread warily and cautiously and ensure that there is a sensible meaning to the use of this so-called plain language which is utilised in this legislative package.

I stress that the Opposition is acting constructively in this matter. We are not point scoring. As I said, we were supportive of suspending Standing Orders in order that this matter could go to a committee so that that committee could get on with the task that we think it is important for it to do. We believe that there is basis for reform of this area of law. We accept that business and the commercial world have changed. We have accepted that business has become more national and is becoming more international. We accept that the regulatory system needs to change along with the changes within which it must operate. We think it is time to consider constructively a transfer of takeover and security law to the Commonwealth. We have accepted that there are benefits in the concept of a close company, an attempt to simplify the small company concept, particularly for the benefit of small business, in circumstances in which companies, in practice, are little more than a partnership. We are supportive of that type of constructive reform.

We accept the failure of proper parliamentary accountability in the existing system and that that must be addressed. I am a little disappointed that the Government did not accept a long time ago the advice of the former member for Hawker, Mr Jacobi, who wanted to set up a joint select committee of the Parliament to look at the matters that have been thrust upon us by the Government in this way. I suspect that had the Government taken the path that he advocated some time ago we would have before us now a much more realistic package of Bills. We support the need for reform. We are not attempting to retard reform where it is shown to be necessary. But we do say that business and the professions in this area expect certainty in the law that we pass and, at the very least, that certainty is very much put in jeopardy by the package of Bills before us.

The first critical question on the subject of doubtful certainty is that of the constitutionality of this package of Bills. I want to spend a few minutes looking at that matter, because I think it is of fundamental importance to this debate. It has long been thought that, for the Commonwealth to have power to support a package of Bills of this breadth, it would require constitutional change. Historically, proposals to extend the Commonwealth's power over corporations were proposed and defeated in referenda in 1911, 1913, 1919 and 1926. In 1929 the Royal Commission on the Constitution recommended that the Constitution be amended to confer power on the Commonwealth in legislative form in this area. In 1959, the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review recommended that the Constitution be amended to grant the Commonwealth concurrent legislative power over corporations. As late as 1987, this Government's advisory committee to the Constitutional Commission on trade and national economic management recommended constitutional reform to overcome doubts that existed as to the constitutional competence of the Commonwealth Government to support legislation of this type.

Throughout the history of the Commonwealth we have seen a recognition by learned bodies after due consideration that the constitutional basis for this type of reform is very much in doubt. I remind honourable senators that the advisory committee that I mentioned, comprised of senior lawyers and businessmen, reported only three months after the report of the then Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs was brought down. It came to its conclusion on the basis of advice of eminent lawyers, despite the opinion of Sir Maurice Byers, which was relied on by the Senate Committee.

Many eminent lawyers in this country very much question the opinion that was given by Sir Maurice Byers to that Committee and upon which that Committee was able to make certain recommendations. Even the Attorney-General's Department, in its submission to the Senate Committee, made clear that it had doubts as to the constitutional validity of a full takeover of law in this area. The submission recommended a split scheme with a transfer of takeover and security law-the type of scheme that has some appeal to those on this side of the chamber. The submission to the Senate Committee stated, `There is still room for doubt in some of these areas'. So in 1986 the Department itself was in doubt in relation to this matter.

Apart from the Senate Standing Committee and the advice it received, since this matter has been on the table for debates an endless list of eminent lawyers in this country have said that the Commonwealth is going too far, that it is going beyond its constitutional competence. I refer briefly to the joint memorandum of the Solicitors-General of each of the States and the Northern Territory which was produced earlier this year as a result of a meeting on 9 March 1988 in which they unanimously questioned the Commonwealth's legal competence in this area. They questioned it in relation to the capacity of those parts of the Bills that relate to incorporation, internal regulation and trading in company shares. I do not have time to refer to it in depth. Because it is a most important memorandum and because of its brevity, I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Corporations Power Constitution Section 51(xx)

The Attorneys General of the States and the Northern Territory requested their respective Solicitors General acting as a body to provide a joint memorandum setting out their views as to the scope of Commonwealth power to enact a comprehensive Companies and Securities Code pursuant to s51(xx) of the Constitution. That provision empowers the Commonwealth to pass laws with respect to:
``foreign corporations, and trading or financial corporations formed within the limits of the Commonwealth''.

The Solicitors General for New South Wales, Northern Territory, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania and representatives of the Solicitor General of Western Australia met in Sydney on 9 March 1988 to prepare this memorandum. The Solicitor General for Victoria was unable to attend.
Those who prepared this memorandum had regard to the views expressed in the publications and opinions mentioned in the Appendix.
Joint Advice
1.1 There seems to be no doubt that the Commonwealth can legislate in respect of the following-

1.1.1 A corporation whose trading or financial activities are a significant part of its business. It does not matter that the corporation would be characterised as something else, e.g. a local government corporation, a sporting body or a credit union. (It does not extend to State banking or State insurance within the limits of the State concerned.)

It will sometimes be unclear whether a company is a trading or financial corporation. If its character depends on its activities, a corporation could move in and out of the field of Commonwealth control as its activities change (with obvious administrative and other problems).
1.1.2 All the business activities of such corporations, including things done for the purpose of (i.e. preparatory or ancillary to) such activities.

1.2 The extent of the Commonwealth's power under s51(xx) is such that it may legislate with respect to a wide range of bodies corporate including statutory corporations such as State power authorities and quite possibly education, hospital and local government corporations.

1.3 The matters which are clearly or probably within Commonwealth power are most of those covered by the existing Companies Codes but not those parts relating to incorporation, internal regulation and trading in company shares (as to which see (3) below).
2. There is doubt as to whether the Commonwealth can rely on its corporations power to legislate with respect to the non-business activities of trading or financial corporations.
3. The Commonwealth clearly cannot rely upon its corporations power to legislate in respect of corporations which are not trading or financial corporations.

4. The ability to legislate comprehensively in respect of trading or financial corporations is fundamental to the establishment by the Commonwealth of any viable scheme. No scheme could operate effectively which did not cover the inter-related matter of incorporation, internal regulation and trading in company shares.

5. There is at least a reasonable prospect that the High Court will conclude that the corporations power of the Commonwealth does not extend to these matters. The opinions of the Solicitors General as to the prospect of establishing invalidity of legislation extending to these matters ranged from evenly balanced through to quite good. A dual system of regulation of trading of financial corporations would then be necessary.
6. The following are some of the problems which a dual system of regulation of trading or financial corporations would be likely to create:

6.1 To enact a coded limited application in such important matters is to run the risk of serious confusion developing. A dual system would inevitably lead to the several States requiring their own legislation and administrative structures to cover all that was beyond Commonwealth power. The result would be duplication of administration, increased cost, `demarcation' disputes and generally a downgrading of the system presently in place. Commercially it could be chaotic.

6.2 Such a system would be very difficult to police and enforce. Currently there is a high level of successful co-operation between State police and Corporate Affairs officers in relation to the investigation and prosecution of crime corporate and otherwise. No jurisdictional problems exist. Investigation by authorities required to differentiate between Commonwealth and State offences could become unnecessarily complex.

6.3 One can say fairly confidently that a dual system, attracting as it must many of the aforementioned problems, would not be palatable to the business community and would give rise to serious inefficiencies.

7. If the Commonwealth cannot legislate in respect of incorporation and internal regulation it does not seem feasible for it to regulate the securities industry. If it cannot regulate trading in shares or corporations as such it will have to base its controls on corporations acquiring securities, acting as brokers and acting as advisers. This would be an inadequate scheme. Only corporations within s51(xx) would be bound. Individuals and other corporations would not be. There would be no control over large parts of the investment advising industry. If those engaged in the industry adopted a non-corporate structure they would escape the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will simply quote one sentence:

SPEECH.PARA: There is at least a reasonable prospect that the High Court will conclude that the corporations power of the Commonwealth does not extend to these matters.

The Solicitors-General of almost every State are listed: New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania, a representative of the Solicitor-General of Western Australia, and also the Northern Territory. The Victorian Solicitor-General was unable to attend. In those circumstances where the most eminent crown lawyers in each of the States say that the Government's proposed package is in jeopardy, should the Senate be proceeding with a narrowly based inquiry or should it have an inquiry that includes this constitutional question?

I draw the Senate's attention to the opinion of the Law Institute of Victoria which was given only in August this year and which supports the document that I have incorporated. That opinion indicates that that organisation very much doubts that the Commonwealth has the powers which it believes it has, and brings into question directly the opinion of Sir Maurice Byers. It believes in a number of areas-in incorporation as well as other areas-the Commonwealth does not have the power that it claims it has.

The opinion of the Law Institute goes on to mention that if part of these Bills were found to be invalid-which it fears would be the case-it would result in `catastrophic effects to trade and commerce within Australia and between Australia and the rest of the world'. That is a serious opinion from the Law Institute of Victoria and one of Australia's leading commercial firms, Mallesons Stephen Jaques. It says that the Commonwealth does not have the power and furthermore that the effect of this package going ahead could be to lead to catastrophic effects. The inquiry being proposed by the Democrats does not deal with that wider question at all.

I draw to your attention, Mr Acting Deputy President, the view of the Law Council of Australia, not lightly to be dismissed, I would have thought. In its advice put out on 31 August of this year-again, only a month or so ago-it says that it has doubts whether the Commonwealth has the constitutional power that it claims. The advice states:

It believes that it would be irresponsible for the Commonwealth to legislate on the basis of its existing constitutional powers. The Commonwealth should not legislate unless and until the Constitution has been appropriately amended . . .

That is a statement from an opinion put out only a month ago by the Law Council of Australia, the most senior legal professional body in this country. It would be irresponsible for the Federal Government to go ahead on the current basis but that is what it is seeking to do. I would have thought that in the light of all this eminent advice the Government would have bowed to the consensus of the legal views in this country and acknowledged that there is a serious doubt that catastrophic consequences could follow.

Just imagine for a moment the consequences if incorporation of a company is found to be invalid and shareholders lose the corporate veil of limited liability because this Government has pushed through unconstitutional legislation. I wonder whether the shareholders within Australia would understand the prospects and consequences if that occurred. Why, in these circumstances, does the Government insist on going ahead and refusing this Parliament a broad-based inquiry? That is beyond me.

I have said that the package also fails to have the confidence of the States. I have indicated that it fails to have the confidence of the legal profession. Very briefly, I will put to the Senate the facts of why it fails to have the confidence of business. I refer to a press release put out by the Australian Chamber of Commerce in July of this year, only a short time ago. It states:
The Federal Attorney-General should not proceed with the proposed new national system of companies and securities laws.
The Federal Government does not have the necessary support of commerce and industry within this country, especially small business . . .
The Institute of Chartered Secretaries and Administrators, representing over 10,000 company secretaries and corporate managers, in a letter of 5 July said:
The necessary reforms . . . can be achieved within the framework of the existing scheme . . .
The case to dismantle the existing scheme and to replace it with a Federal scheme does not appear to have been made.

The more the Confederation of Australian Industry thought about and considered the matter the less it was impressed. On 10 July and subsequently by press release on 29 September it made clear that it did not wish this package to proceed. The Australian Merchant Bankers Association, also in July of this year, called upon the Government not to proceed. It also made reference to the lack of proper and effective consultation which is something that causes us concern.

If I can be parochial for a moment, I will look at my home State of South Australia. I have submissions from the Australian Stock Exchange Adelaide Ltd; the Law Society of South Australia; the South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy; the Institute of Directors, South Australian branch; the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, South Australia; the Australian Society of Accountants, South Australia; the Institute of Chartered Accountants, South Australia; the South Australian Employers Federation; and the Insolvency Practitioners of Australia, South Australia branch. They all oppose what the Commonwealth is seeking to do. Similar bodies in each of the States also have a similar view. I do not have time to go through their arguments today but they are concerned about the loss of accessibility to regulatory authorities. They are concerned about the loss of expertise within the professions that would occur. They are concerned about the extra costs that the business sector would incur in complying with a central scheme and the need for travel, possibly to Melbourne, as Senator Macklin said in relation to these matters. We have business and the professions throughout Australia opposed to what the Government has been doing. If the Government is not going to consult with them, why should not the Parliament consult and therefore be of some assistance in this legislative process? The Government should find out what their concerns are, find out if there is a way of building their confidence, putting forward a scheme that can achieve objectives that we want but with its support.

The Government set up what it called its consultative procedure, a series of four subcommittees including accounting, administration, implementation, legal and securities. They were to consult within their relevant professional areas and advise the Government. On 6 July I wrote to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and asked whether we, the Parliament, could have copies of these reports upon which the Government was going to act. I have not received a reply. I certainly have not been able to see any of the reports. We do not know what advice each of these groups gave the Attorney-General. Why can they not be on the table so that we can all have their views or is it the case that the subcommittees rarely met and produced little? In other words, it became a sham. As my colleague Mr Moore, the honourable member for Ryan, said, two members of the advisory committee rang him after the Government put forward its amendments and asked him what the Government was seeking to amend. They were not involved in the process to any great extent at all. It was a sham to produce an image that business and the professions were supporting this package and it has not worked. The business and the professions simply are not supporting it.

The States are opposed to it. The vast proportion of the business sector is opposed to it, with the possible exception of the Business Council of Australia. We have the professions opposing it; we have the consultative process which became a sham; and we have a constitutional question which is highly doubtful. In all of these circumstances the Government and the Democrats are going to refuse the Parliament the opportunity to look at these fundamental questions. As I said, it is our view that the Parliament should be looking at the wider questions.

With some regret I say that I suspect that the Senate Committee erred in so readily accepting the opinion of Sir Maurice Byers. Now that we have so many other eminent lawyers that have questioned that opinion I regret that we did not seek further opinions before we came to our conclusions. Perhaps we acted from a frustration which we have found in this place that the Senate is being turned into a rubber stamp by the existing scheme. Not surprisingly, we in this place believe in proper parliamentary accountability. We would like to see progressive moves towards greater parliamentary accountability in this area. We said that the system requires reform but what we are saying is that the Government is going about it the wrong way. If the Government, with the support of the States-I believe it could have got the support of the States and business-had looked at a transfer of takeovers and securities law that would have been another large area which would have come within proper Commonwealth parliamentary accountability and would have been a move in the right direction. It would have been done with the support of all these bodies rather than them being against it. That would have been a better way for it to go. Alternatively, no doubt there are very worthwhile reforms within this package. They could have been introduced within the cooperative scheme and given an opportunity to work in practice before the more fundamental changes were brought to the Parliament. That would have been a constructive move the Government could have undertaken.

What the Government could have done, and still can do, is make considerable administrative improvements to the existing system. It comes to us wanting this massive reform at a time when due to failure on its own part the existing system is not working as well as it could be. For example, I mention the funding for the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). We are all critical of aspects of the NCSC from time to time but it is inadequately funded. It cannot carry out the function that it is legislatively required to carry out because this Government will not allow it sufficient funding to do so.

Similarly, the Corporate Affairs Commission in each of the States, particularly in relation to the investigatory arms of the CAC, is unable to carry out its functions adequately because it is starved of resources. Officers within those sections are unsure of their future and are unable to be presented with adequate career structures so the best personnel are leaving. We have a situation where administratively the Government could have much improved the situation in corporate law in this country. Instead, it seeks to bring to us such a major and fundamental change which is so very doubtfully constitutionally valid.

In conclusion, the Opposition is seeking to refer this matter to the Committee for wider consideration, that is, for consideration of the legitimate needs of the business community and the States; to look at the potential for a split scheme; to modify the present cooperative scheme; to look at the question of constitutional validity; and to look seriously at the concerns that have been raised in each of the States by business and professional bodies. I urge that the Senate accept the amendment that has been moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. The Senate is considering the reference of a package of some 16 Bills to a joint select committee of both Houses of Parliament. The second reading speech on the Corporations Bill 1988 which was incorporated in Hansard by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill amalgamates into one law the areas presently covered by the separate cooperative scheme codes, namely the Companies Code, the Acquisition of Shares Code, the Securities Industry Code and the Futures Industry Code.
Further on it states:

In the drafting of the national law, the opportunity has been taken to introduce a number of substantial reforms in areas of the law that have been bedevilling the business community because of the excessive and unnecessary regulations imposed. If there is an appeal, that is, if there is action taken by the States to the High Court after these measures have gone through, the whole of the business community in Australia will be in utter chaos. Senator Macklin's motion states:

. . . the Committee inquire into and report on the Bills for the regulation of companies and the securities and futures industries with reference only to the adequacy of the proposed legislative provisions to:
(a) improve the regulation of companies;
(b) facilitate the performance of the securities and futures markets; and
(c) ensure adequate protection for investors in companies and the securities and futures markets;
and, in particular, report on the adequacy of the fund-raising provisions.

So far so good. Senator Hill has moved an amendment which would enable the Committee to do all of that. The amendment makes it clear that there should be an examination and report to us in the Senate to examine the Bill for unintended legal and commercial consequences and to report whether the Bills and the scheme thereby created meet the legitimate needs of the business community, all State governments and other interested groups within the community. I will not read it but it does open the field quite broadly. It has benefits but it has one problem. The scheme of select committees in the Parliament is a method of exercising the representative function of individual members of parliament. In other words, there is an advertisement for the calling of submissions; the submissions are made and the committee considers them thoroughly and makes recommendations to the Parliament. That is very helpful for those of us who will not be on the committee. It is particularly helpful in a case like this where we have 16 Bills covering a very substantial number of pages and clauses.

Frankly, it would be most beneficial if the inquiry was able to go into these areas of principle and not stick strictly to the technicalities of the legislation. The difficulty with that is that it could be an inquiry which could go on from here until the end of this century. TALK.START.PARA: —It is the first day back.

—Under those circumstances, I am satisfied with the proposal put forward by Senator Hill. That was one thing I was concerned about because there are very grave questions bedevilling not only the business community but also consumers in this whole area.
