SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be supporting Senator Macklin's motion to refer the Corporations Bill and related Bills to a joint select committee. Therefore, of course we will be opposing the amendment to that motion moved by Senator Hill. We will do so because we believe that the process of deliberation on this very considerable package of Bills will be greatly enhanced by the use-I think it is a very innovative, sensible and creative use-of the committee system of this Parliament. The fact is that the package of Bills, as has been stated many times, is a very large one and I believe that no senator in this chamber, in which we take our deliberative and review duties very seriously, could very sensibly claim that he was ready for a debate on this package without the aid of his colleagues on a committee, perhaps to go through it in the sort of detail and with the sorts of witnesses that would help, as I say, to clarify, and perhaps make more sensible, some of the very difficult and technical drafting that occurs. However, in saying all that I do not want to give the impression, which I know is perhaps being put by Senator Hill, that a committee set up under the terms of Senator Macklin's proposal would somehow be confined merely to checking on the terminology that is used-I think Senator Hill referred at one time to the `sensible use of words'-the plain English and the certainty in law that Senator Hill was seeking by the actual use of terms and expressions that carry definite legal meaning. The role of the committee as proposed by Senator Macklin would not be merely a narrow, technical review of the terms and expressions used. If we look at the wording of his motion we see that it would be somewhat wider. At the end of the preambular paragraph he states that the task of the proposed committee would be to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . inquire into and report on the Bills for the regulation of companies and the securities and futures industries with reference only to the adequacy of the proposed legislative provisions to:
(a) improve the regulation of companies;
(b) facilitate the performance of the securities and futures markets; and
(c) ensure adequate protection for investors in companies and the securities and futures markets;
and, in particular, report on the adequacy of the fund-raising provisions.

I believe that in that terminology, talking about the adequacy of the provisions to achieve those ends, the committee in its deliberations will have the capacity to bring in qualitative judgments as to the way in which the Bills achieve those particular ends. I believe in that sense the role of the committee goes far beyond a merely technical review of the drafting. It will be looking at the adequacy of the legislative provisions to achieve those very important ends. The proposed ends-to improve the regulation of companies, to facilitate the performance of the securities and futures markets and ensure adequate protection for investors in companies and the securities and futures markets-give the committee a very wide capability to undertake the sort of qualitative scrutiny of the legislation of which I speak. Of course, in looking at those terms of reference (a), (b) and (c), one realises that in a sense (c) should precede (b) because it is only if we are satisfied that the legislation adequately ensures protection for investors that the performance of the securities and futures markets will be facilitated. The protection of investors will engender the confidence that will facilitate the performance of those markets. Therefore, there is plenty of scope for qualitative, not merely technical, drafting scrutiny to be undertaken by the committee as proposed by Senator Macklin.

The constitutional status of the legislative package has been raised. Of course, that is a proper question to raise. Indeed, there have been expressions of opinion from various sources as to the constitutional validity of the whole scheme. However, I will repeat what was said by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in letters to all the State Attorneys-General on 29 April this year:

It is the Government's intention that, following passage, commencement of the legislation would be held back if it has become clear by then that a State or Territory Government proposes to initiate a comprehensive challenge to the constitutional validity of the legislation. In these circumstances, the Government would seek to have the resolution of any such challenge handled as expeditiously as possible.

This was made a public document back in April. In other words, the Government recognises that upon the enactment of this legislative package by the Federal Parliament a State or Territory may well indicate that it wishes to test the matter before the High Court of Australia. It would be sensible in that situation that the proclamation of the commencement of the legislation be delayed until that particular matter was resolved. In other words, we would not be seeking an advisory opinion on the Bills but a decision by the High Court on the constitutional validity of the legislation. It would not be brought into operation in a way which would induce or require action by people in reliance on it which, as has been pointed out, could then be undone if a comprehensive challenge to the constitutional validity succeeded. In that regard there has already been an indication of the way in which the underlying validity of the scheme could be properly tested in a way which would not wreak the havoc that, it has been put to us, would occur under the scenario put forward by Senator Hill.

Having said that, of course the Government has brought this legislation into the Parliament in the view and with the confidence that it can be supported by constitutional power. As the Senate would expect, not only has the corporations power been relied on in the undergirding power base for this legislation but also it is reinforced by a wide range of other powers, such as the powers to regulate interstate trade and commerce, post and telecommunications, banking, insurance, cheques and negotiable instruments. Indeed I believe that if tested the legislative package would survive. I think those points deal with the worst scenario put forward by Senator Hill and indicate why the Government is not minded to support a proposition that the whole question of constitutional validity be sent to a Senate committee. We do not think that that is a proper way for that matter to be dealt with and determined. In fact, it could not be determined by the Senate committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is only one of the items.

—I know it is only one of the items, and I will come to the others in a moment-I will come to them now if Senator Crichton-Browne likes. I believe that the idea of the joint parliamentary committee proposed by Senator Macklin not only has merit for the task it is being asked to perform by the terms of reference he has proposed that it be given but also, as he has indicated, it could well be a forerunner to a standing committee which would have the superintendence and supervision of this whole body of legislation once it is passed. I can see great merit in that. I believe that such a standing committee would achieve an expertise that would be extremely helpful to the Parliament when it came to the amendment and passage of new legislation within the framework that we are trying to establish in this package.
—You mean a committee set up to make bad legislation good?

—Not at all. As put forward by Senator Macklin there have been examples in the electoral law area, the National Crime Authority area and, I think, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation area of standing committees being established for the superintendence of legislation and these have proved to be very successful. I believe that that would certainly be the case here. It would help meet one of the great concerns which led to the former Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs first concluding and recommending, as a result of a very comprehensive inquiry, `that the Commonwealth Parliament should enact comprehensive legislation covering the field currently regulated by the cooperative scheme'. That is the sort of committee support which Senator Macklin's Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs foreshadows would be very helpful in enabling this Parliament to discharge properly its democratic role in taking responsibility for the regulation of these areas.

SPEECH.PARA: The actual terms of reference put forward as an alternative by Senator Hill, I believe, on the whole are not fully reflective of the reality. For example, his amendment speaks of the passage of the Bills resulting in `the loss by the State regulatory authorities and their respective business communities of accessibility and the ability to influence policy and law-making', which, as Senator Crichton-Browne will know, has been a very strong claim, particularly in Western Australia, but also in some of the regional areas of Australia. Once again, in the document of 29 April to which I have already referred, the Attorney-General, in writing to his counterparts in the States and the Northern Territory, made this point, which I think is worth reading out:

The legislation will provide that where the Government of a State or Territory, by agreement with the Commonwealth Government, makes available an agency of its administration to administer the legislation as a delegate of the ASC, the ASC shall, in performing its functions and exercising its powers, including the power of delegation, ensure that the administration of those laws is carried out, to the maximum extent practicable, by that agency of the State or Territory administration, subject to direction of the ASC (cf. Formal Agreement, Cl. 37).
Importantly, it goes on:

It is envisaged that such agreements would recognise that State and the Northern Territory Government agencies, in addition to administering laws as delegates of the ASC, would be able to administer other State and Territory laws. Terms and conditions of the employment of personnel of the State and Territory Government agencies would be a matter for the respective governments, subject to the ASC having a capacity to arrange for officers employed by one Government to be seconded to work for extended periods, if necessary, in the companies and securities agency of another Government (e.g. as a member of an investigation task force involving officers from the ASC and more than 1 State or Territory).

In other words, there is an understanding there of the very real role that the regional offices will be playing and, in that situation, the accessibility of and the ability to communicate quickly with the locally available office of the Australian Securities Commission would be secured. I believe that that is something which a State which was minded to ensure that accessibility and easy communication would take up, to ensure that the particular offer by the Attorney-General became a reality.

Perhaps one of the key clauses in Senator Hill's terms of reference speaks of `the interests of shareholders and the broad community being adequately protected by the Bills', and that is very much at the heart of what Senator Macklin proposes and is almost word for word one of the terms of reference put forward by Senator Macklin. That is one of the key areas which, as I have said, will be able to be reported on by the committee within Senator Macklin's terms of reference.

I believe that the terms of reference put forward by Senator Macklin at least make an innovative use of the parliamentary committee system. I think the terms of reference are such that they will enable the committee to get beyond technicalities-they are much wider than that-and will enable it to make qualitative judgments about the accuracy of the proposed legislative provisions to achieve their primary ends, which are very important ends. Indeed, those objectives, goals and ends were recognised as important, as we have a national securities and futures market engaged in international trade and commerce to the ever-quickening degree that has been apparent in our community over the last several years. I believe that there is great scope for this committee to give a very useful report to the chambers of this Parliament before we come to debate the matter. I think Senator Macklin is to be congratulated for putting before the Senate in this first instance a mechanism which will enable this Parliament to discharge its duties so much better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is opposed to the limited nature of the proposed committee to inquire into and report upon the Bills making up the corporate package and thus has offered the amendment, as moved by Senator Hill, which will broaden the inquiry and look at the real problems and issues in the massive tomes of legislation which will so fundamentally alter the law governing the activities of corporations and business generally in this country. Senator Tate, in his response, has sought to eulogise the terms of reference used by the Australian Democrats and has stressed that he believes that they are not as narrow as they would first appear. He seems to be saying that he would like it both ways. He has done a deal with the Democrats, so he has to support their motion, but he is saying that he is in a difficult position, just as he was with regard to the referendums, and he does not really believe in what he has to espouse. Thus, he says, the terms of reference put forward by the Democrats will allow for the wider terms of inquiry that our proposal sets out so clearly. That being the case, the clear and proper course of action would be to put the breadth of the inquiry beyond doubt and simply to accept the amendment as we have put it forward.

SPEECH.PARA: When looking at the reasons why we require the broader terms of reference, I think three points need to be covered. The first is the Government's assertion that there has been a great consultative process with business and with other parts of the community on the advisability and desirability of this legislation. Secondly, there is the drafting question: not only the new use of the so-called plain English terms but also the manner in which it is drafted with overlapping provisions. Thirdly, there is the constitutionality question-whether or not there is power for the Commonwealth to make a takeover from the States.

As I am a senator from New South Wales, I would like to put clearly the New South Wales Government's position: the New South Wales Government holds the view that any change that comes about should be through an in-depth consultation. Changes should be made to the individual State's laws, not overridden by the Federal Government. That view is shared by all other States. So we are coming to the conclusion again that, whereas the Government is asserting that it has support for its proposal, the reality is that it does not.

The Government initially set up a small consultative group and said that it was looking at a proposed eight or nine areas of reform which basically people in industry agreed needed to be looked at. A steering committee was established and then various subcommittees were established. The evidence that is available seems to show that the consultative group and, in particular, the subcommittees have not met in anything like a regular fashion and that the examination of work simply has not gone through. I think Senator Hill and Mr Moore in the House of Representatives pointed out that two members of those groups had to ring Mr Moore to ask him about the nature of the 280 amendments that were introduced into the House of Representatives because-surprise, surprise!-they had not been consulted. Just as the Government claimed in the referendum issues that it had business support for the so-called four-year term proposal, which, as we all know, was a grab at trying to lessen the powers of the Senate, what we saw was a public relations exercise in an attempt to say that business was on side. Again, we have the same public relations exercise by the Government, trying to make this assertion. Quite clearly, the various business groups that may have been interested in the question of reform when it was initially put forward and covered eight or nine topics have seen the size of this enormous package of Bills. The size of the Corporations Bill itself will be beaten in size only by the taxation legislation. They took a look at the size of the pile of Bills-if we had television in this chamber I could demonstrate by putting them on a desk-and, looking at the size of them--

TALK.START.PARA: —A hurdle.

—Yes, a hurdle might be the way to describe the size of them. The various industry groups have now deserted the Labor Party's push for power. Indeed, as Senator Hill mentioned, the Confederation of Australian Industry has taken a very strong stance. In its Press release dated 29 September it stated that it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . favours positive reforms being made to the existing co-operative scheme in order to achieve these objectives. CAI believes that both State, Territory and Federal Governments should work together not merely to achieve political expediency but to deliver real benefits to the whole community . . .

It is just the same as the proposition in the referendum debate-the Government said it was desirable for the whole community but it was really only in the interests of the Government. We have an analogy here. Again, this is government driven. The community at large does not want the legislation introduced, yet the Government is pushing ahead at all costs and, of course, this time it does not have to ask the people.

It is interesting that the referendums and the proposed corporate package have another thing in common. Lionel Bowen is clearly in his dying days of being in the Parliament. He wanted to retire in glory with his memorials intact. He wanted to say he was the man who had been able to bring about constitutional change and had dramatically altered the face of corporate law in this country. The people were involved in the first part, and they gave him a resounding, an overwhelming, no vote-the greatest no vote, the greatest rebuff, to any government at any time in a referendum. This time we are looking at trying to let the people have a voice, by setting up a committee to inquire into those aspects which will adversely affect the community and the business climate in general.

The second point I mention is the drafting question and the use of new plain English. Many people would like definitive meanings to many terms that are used in drafting legislation and regulations and interpretations that flow from that. Over the years a collective body of words with precise meanings has been used in drafting legislation. By using this new form of plain English drafting, which I think first came into vogue in Victoria, the meaning of sections of Acts will be uncertain. It will be up to the litigants to underwrite the cost of expensive litigation to find out finally what this new legislation will mean. When one couples that with the way in which the legislation has been drafted, with overlapping provisions, so that in the event that one provision is struck down another one may come into operation, one sees that the draftsmen are using what is very much a lazy man's way of trying to express, in legislative form, what is debated in this chamber. This was commented upon by Sir Garfield Barwick when he was Chief Justice. He warned against this type of drafting, adding that it was no doubt convenient for parliamentary draftsmen to avoid the risk of unconstitutionality by using statutory definitions, but he warned that it was not in the interests of the community at large. However, the draftsmen have chosen-no doubt with the concurrence of the Government-to use this form.

I now turn to the much more vexing question of constitutionality and whether the Federal Government has power to introduce legislation to cover the field in corporate law. It is interesting that the Government has, once again, trotted out its pet legal guru, Sir Maurice Byers, who first entered the fray on this question in 1974-75 when the Whitlam Government tried to introduce similar legislation. Sir Maurice Byers wrote an opinion in 1974 that it was constitutional to regulate in the area that this legislation proposes. That proposed legislation lapsed on 11 November 1975. So this is not a new try, a new debate.

Sir Maurice Byers was then invited by the Attorney-General's Department to give a legal opinion to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. It is quite clear from paragraph 5.6, at page 66 of its report, that the advice provided by Sir Maurice Byers, QC, was provided to the Senate Committee at the request of the Federal Attorney-General's Department. The Committee had no choice as to who was to provide the opinion. Again, the Attorney-General trotted out his pet guru-Sir Maurice Byers, who has left the legal arena behind and is now in the political arena-to give a legal opinion which would support the Government's proposition that there was power to introduce legislation covering the corporate law field.

When that Committee reported it relied very heavily on that opinion. Today Senator Hill said that the Committee, with hindsight, perhaps regretted that it had relied too heavily on that opinion and if it had its druthers, or another opportunity, it clearly would not do so. It is interesting to note that Sir Maurice, after the devastating defeat of the referendums in which he again was so intimately involved as Chairman of the Constitutional Commission-he was involved in debating the issues in public forums, both on television and in public meeting places-was quoted as saying on the front page of the Australian that we were in a very dangerous economic position. He said that the only way out of it was for the Constitution to be altered to give the Commonwealth Government control over industrial relations, incorporation of companies, trading and financial and other markets. It clearly indicates that his overall original opinion cannot really be relied upon. He originally said that we had to alter the Constitution to allow those things to happen. He is now purporting to say that, indeed, there is power under the Constitution to introduce this legislation. Even on his own admission, there is much doubt.

As I pointed out before in this chamber, Sir Maurice has been known to be wrong on several, if not many, occasions. On a previous occasion I cited two cases-Clunies-Ross v. The Commonwealth, and the Collector of Customs v. Lawler Automotives Pty Ltd-in which he, when he was Solicitor-General, was found against. The reliance that the Government places on Sir Maurice Byers for saying that it has the power to introduce its legislation and it knows what it is doing is clearly not a sound proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that's a bit tough.

—The reality is that Sir Maurice has moved out of the legal arena and has become a political player. On a Face to Face encounter I had the opportunity to say to Sir Maurice that when one moves out of the legal arena into the political arena the rules change. It is not at all a bit tough.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note the remarks of Mr William Beerworth, Executive Director of Wardley Australia Ltd, who, in a speech delivered on 29 September in Melbourne, said:

There was a time when I was regarded as an angry young Turk in companies and securities law in Australia. But that was in 1973, when I was working with Lionel Murphy and after I had spent years studying and working in securities regulation in the United States.
He then went on:
15 years later, I must recognise that the wheel has come full circle. Like some of you, I have an enormous sense of deja vu. This is not a new debate.
In that speech, which was several pages long, he concluded:

Regrettably, we appear to be on an absolute collision course between the Commonwealth and the States with the Commonwealth unable to accept that there really are major constitutional problems which will cause enormous expense, uncertainty and inconvenience for business. I am very much afraid that the Commonwealth has taken the same approach in relation to these issues as it took in relation to the constitutional amendments: it has rushed them on, misdescribed them, over-promoted them and been surprised by the public reaction.

Those remarks are really quite interesting when the Government claims that it has business support. Of course, the Government has a fall-back mechanism. The Government has acknowledged that the legislation will be challenged. It says that it welcomes the challenge and will deal with it expeditiously. But the manner in which those Bills have been drafted means that should the memorandum of understanding pursuant to the closer economic relations arrangement with New Zealand take on the nature of a treaty, the Government could use the external affairs power to introduce its entire corporate package.

Sir Maurice Byers has gone on record as saying that to achieve the things that he wants to see-that is, the total transfer of power in this area to the Commonwealth-it would require constitutional change. He has looked defeat in the face when constitutional change was tried in relation to giving more power to Canberra on other issues. We are now seeing the spectre of an attempt by the Government to render the Constitution irrelevant. We have seen the external affairs power used in the dams case. There are those who might think that that power is limited in its operation to areas concerning the environment, but that is clearly not the case. The external affairs power is wide and unbridled in the way in which the High Court has interpreted it. It could well be that this legislation will be passed, challenged by a State or Territory government, held to be unconstitutional under the corporate affairs power of section 51, and yet subsequently found to be able to be passed under the external affairs power.

That is the nature of the real objective of this Government. It is determined to snatch the area of corporate law away from the States and to centralise it here in Canberra. But as usual, the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, is not on top of his brief. He was not on top of his brief on the constitutional referendums and he clearly put his foot in it quite often. He was one of our best assets. In relation to this corporate legislation, he is also not on top of his brief. We saw the introduction of 280 amendments after the Bills were introduced in May. I put it to the Senate this way: the sloppiness of the Attorney-General's Department is such that if one's life depended on it and the only legal advice and representation available was from the Attorney-General's Department, one would be better off appearing for oneself. The nature of the Department's work is clearly sloppy.

The amendment that the Opposition has moved to the Australian Democrats' motion this morning would allow the proper examination of the whole ambit of constitutionality and drafting questions and allow proper consultation. It would offer a fair involvement of the community, both business and people at large who are interested in this debate. But once again it seems that we are to be forced into debating this legislation in a premature way without a proper examination because the Attorney-General wants his monument. This is not the way to run a government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Hill's amendment and to reflect in a not particularly generous way on the restrictive nature of the Australian Democrats' proposal. The contrast between the two is striking, but predictable. I was interested to hear Senator Macklin describe this package of Bills-the 1,300 clauses, the 3,000 pages-as fascinating reading, fascinating Bills. Only the Democrats would find fascination in legislation of this nature, designed again to centralise in the rarefied air of Canberra what have been historically and intrinsically State responsibilities. It is interesting that the Democrats are concerned only with the fundamental contents of the Bills and in ways of ensuring that these are varied or modified, but not substantially or fundamentally changed.

SPEECH.PARA: The difference between Senator Hill's proposal and that of the Democrats is that Senator Hill is not committing himself to support the legislation and the Democrats are. The reason why the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has congratulated the Democrats and Senator Macklin and is congratulating himself for getting the legislation in the chamber is that both he and the Democrats support it. That is why he supports the Democrats' proposal, because unless he does he will not get the Bills. If our proposals were supported, the Bills-their integrity, competence, merit and justification-would come into question. The fundamental principles of the Bills and the philosophy behind them would be questioned. The general merits of the legislation would all be subject to scrutiny under Senator Hill's proposal, which is certainly not the case with Senator Macklin's proposal.

Senator Tate tells us that this legislation is a new and enlightened step towards enhancing the committee system of this chamber. He referred to previous examples and talked about the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority and the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, saying that they were two examples and this was to be a third. Again, the underlying point is that in respect of the National Crime Authority and the matters touched on by electoral laws, there is bipartisan support in general principle. That is why those committees, by and large, have functioned effectively. This is quite different.

Philosophically the Liberal Party of Australia is opposed to the natural gravitation and centralisation of power, the inexorable trip on which the Government takes itself on a regular basis. The Opposition questions the efficiency of the legislation, but neither the Government nor the Democrats will do that. That leads one to ask why this legislation is before us and what are its justifications. Let us remind ourselves of those matters which Senator Hill proposes we examine and which the Government refuses to entertain. Senator Hill asked that a committee should examine the Bills for unintended legal and commercial consequences and that it should report on whether all State governments and other interested groups in the community support them. I think that without exception-and honourable senators should correct me if I am wrong-every single State government and the Northern Territory are opposed to the legislation. Am I right about that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, including the Labor governments.

—All those bodies, including the Labor governments, that make up the components of the Federation, of the Commonwealth of Australia, are opposed to this. The very founding States which joined together to create this monster are opposed to the legislation. So of course it is unlikely that the Federal Government will include in its terms of reference whether the legislation is satisfactory to the State governments or whether it is in the best interests of a cooperative federalist system. I am reminded of the comments made by the Victorian Attorney-General who, when he was elected Attorney-General, thought that the idea of centralising the system had merit. He said at the outset that he was a centralist rather than a States righter-one of the natural qualifications that one has to have to be a member of the Australian Labor Party. When he became Attorney-General he said that he thought there should be national legislation. He is now of the opinion that a better scheme than the present one could not be evolved. He has said he does not believe that the bureaucrats in Canberra are as close to the business community or the real world as the State people. For most people that would be a very obvious and logical conclusion to arrive at, but the fact that the Labor Attorney-General of Victoria is now so enlightened demonstrates the scope of the opposition to the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General says that he considers it the private view of most members of the Ministerial Council that it works better than the average Cabinet. He says that the problem of accountability is troubling but that the decisions of the Ministerial Council are achieved only after extensive consultation. Of course that is true. If my memory serves me correctly, we embarked on this new system because Senator Tate was sitting in the chamber of the provisional House one day when the Ministerial Council report was tabled foreshadowing legislative amendments. Senator Tate took grave exception to the fact that legislative changes were being foreshadowed to which he had not yet made a contribution as a member of the Senate. Of course, the truth of the matter is that that is a very modest price to pay for having a cooperative arrangement between the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories.

It has been argued that there has been a diminution of ministerial accountability by having the present cooperative arrangements administered by the Ministerial Council. Of course, it is fundamental to misplace the facts in order to maintain that principle. The truth is that every Minister is still accountable and responsible and each of the decisions of the Ministerial Council is made as a result of a majority view of the Ministerial Council. So in fact ministerial responsibility is widened to embrace all the States, the Commonwealth and the Territory. In that way we have total accountability.

Before I leave the question of State government responsibility, let us remember that this proposal by the Commonwealth can succeed only if in some diabolical way we distort the fundamental principles, the underlying intention of the Constitution at the time it was written by the founding fathers and the time it was agreed upon by all States. It was never intended that the Constitution be used in the way which is presently intended by this Government. I assume that the head of power it is looking for primarily flows as a result of the Tasmanian dams decision. That in itself undermined the very principle of federalism. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds, will be late for Question Time today due to a combination of the bringing forward of Question Time to 11.30 a.m. and a delay in arrival of her aircraft from Sydney, where she has been on Government business. —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade why he did not raise the Blenkinsop matter with the Indonesian Foreign Minister when he met him in New York last week.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The very simple answer is that at that stage there had not been a response, either formal or informal, from the Indonesians to the diplomatic note we had passed over, I think, from memory, on 26 September, requesting detailed information as to the nature of the investigations that had occurred and the findings and the proposed course of action in relation to the individuals concerned. The Indonesian reaction which generated the Prime Minister's public statements on this matter came, after I had met with Mr Alatas, from the Indonesian Embassy official here who really generated the Australian concern by saying-as it turned out, quite wrongly-that the case had already been investigated and closed by the Indonesians and it was simply an accident.

ANSWER.PARA: That piece of misinformation was certainly not in my mind when I spoke to Mr Alatas. If that had been the known Indonesian response at that stage I certainly would have raised it with Mr Alatas because it would have become apparent that we had a problem which was more than simply a run of the mill consular problem, which is what it seemed to me when I went to New York. I had been briefed on it but there was nothing to suggest that it was a problem out of the ordinary that could not be solved by ordinary consular and diplomatic channels. One does not raise matters at the most senior possible level unless one has a serious problem, and at the stage I spoke to Mr Alatas we did not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister raised in his answer the action of the Prime Minister in this matter and we learn that the Prime Minister was reacting to a local Indonesian official. I ask therefore: What was the breakdown in communications between the Prime Minister and our own advisers that caused him to abuse Indonesia on Australian national television when at the same time the United Kingdom Government was indicating that it was satisfied the matter was being properly handled?

—I do not accept that premise. The Prime Minister was not abusing Indonesia. He was saying some robust things about particular individuals who could not remotely be thought to have been acting on behalf of the Indonesian Government. There was certainly no hint of suggestion, explicit or implicit, in what the Prime Minister said that the Indonesian Government was at fault, except in so far as the Prime Minister was responding, perfectly understandably, to statements which at that stage were the only official statements we had from the Indonesian Government, namely, the statements of the embassy official here that it was simply an accident and that the investigation had been closed. It became rapidly apparent that that Indonesian official's statement was based on misinformation. It has subsequently been corrected by the embassy and the whole affair has obviously been thoroughly overtaken by subsequent events.
—It is pretty embarrassing.

—It is not a question of any embarrassment to anybody. It has been completely overtaken by events. The Indonesian Foreign Minister has responded in the terms that I announced to this chamber yesterday. It is the Indonesian Foreign Minister who is expressing the hope that this incident will not have any adverse effects on Australian-Indonesian relations. It is obvious that the matter has been the subject of intervention and involvement at the highest level in Indonesia. There is general goodwill on both sides to get the matter resolved, and I am sure it will be.

—Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of reports in which Senator Boswell reportedly claimed at Ravenshoe on 8 October 1988 that the Federal Government is attempting to turn the wet tropics World Heritage area into a Federal territory? Can the Minister tell the Senate whether there is any substance to this claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard from some sources that Senator Boswell made this claim. I heard his personal explanation in the Senate the other day which was made in response, I think, to someone, who is said to be a spokesperson for me, having the temerity to suggest that Senator Boswell's claims were nonsense. Senator Boswell must have been feeling particularly fragile on that occasion. I would have thought that most shadow Ministers would have been able to handle that without jumping up with a personal explanation. Nonetheless, that is what Senator Boswell did and I think that has confused a few more people, so I would like to put the record straight.

ANSWER.PARA: There will be no new Federal territory. Obviously, some people took it seriously. One Australian Democrat senator asked me whether he could be appointed as administrator. I had to inform him not to get too hot to trot just yet. Senator Boswell based his claim on the October report which Australian authorities had put to the World Heritage Committee. Back in June and July was, of course, the time when the Queensland Government sent 22 people on the public purse over there to see whether they could upset the nomination. Of course they failed dismally. If one looks at what was said in that October proposal one will see that Senator Boswell selectively quoted from it and deliberately distorted it. The actual statement reads:

The Federal management approach is founded on a policy of minimal interference with existing agency responsibilities within the wet tropics in so far as this is compatible with effective management of World Heritage principles.

The report says that Australia could give effect to its management obligations through a number of mechanisms such as the existing World Heritage Act, new legislation, appropriate State legislation, or complementary Federal and State legislation. We gave a whole series of options. Senator Boswell, of course, chose to grab one of them, the one, I might say, that is the least favoured, and say that it was a certainty, that it would happen.

Australian World Heritage areas are administered under a variety of management regimes. They can be under State legislation as they are in places, under joint legislation as they are in places, or if one looks at Kakadu under Federal legislation. Fortunately, not all those people who represent conservative politics in Australia are as ignorant as Senator Boswell is about this question. I was discussing with the New South Wales Minister for Environment, Mr Moore, only this morning the possibility of a joint management regime for World Heritage areas in New South Wales. He, of course, supports the concept. So Senator Boswell is, as is so often the case, alone again.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is on to the League of Rights, though.

—He got on to that very late. And he was with it for too long. If we look at the management regimes that are available in the wet tropics, obviously the one that the Commonwealth would favour is cooperation with Queensland. That is what we have been pursuing for a very long time. Senator Boswell would do his constituents in Queensland no end of good if he stopped rabbiting on with nonsense about new Federal territories and looked at what we are trying to look at, the protection of rainforests and of course that being done with an assurance of a sound economic future for north Queensland. That is what the Commonwealth's $75m will do. I can recall former Premier Bjelke-Petersen-I think Senator Boswell will remember him-saying that he would never ever cooperate with us on the Great Barrier Reef. But of course he did and I am sure that in the end we will get that cooperation in Queensland.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. I refer him to prominent reports in this morning's media that the yacht on which the late Mr David Blenkinsop was travelling at the time of his death in Indonesia was under surveillance by Australian drug authorities. I also refer to the apparent confirmation of this fact on the AM program today by Mr Bob Spanswick of the Customs Officers Association who said that Customs intelligence indicated that the bilges of the vessel concerned had been modified to accommodate the transport of narcotics. In view of the pain these reports are causing to members of Mr Blenkinsop's family, and in light of the very high profile the Government has given to this matter this week, can the Minister tell the Senate whether there is any firm evidence linking the deceased with illegal activities or whether these reports have exaggerated the situation and reflect unfairly on his activities?

—The Australian Federal Police has become aware of certain allegations that have been made in relation to Mr Blenkinsop and drugs. There has been no link whatsoever between the death of Mr Blenkinsop and the suggestions and allegations referred to. I certainly know of no firm evidence of such a link. As I said, the Australian Federal Police has certain intelligence, but certainly there had been no surveillance-I think that was the terminology Senator Chaney took up from some radio broadcast-of Mr Blenkinsop by the Australian Federal Police.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to try to give me some answer to the question which I have asked him. Is he in a position to clarify this position for the public, given that the Government has raised this to a very high profile through the Prime Minister's rather extraordinary intervention? Can the Minister clarify whether there is any concern or evidence of the sort which has been reported and confirmed by an official who is after all an agent of this Government-he is a public servant. He has suggested that there is evidence of modification of this vessel. Can the Minister also tell us whether the report in this morning's paper is correct, that the Prime Minister learned of this surveillance only after his strong attack on the Indonesian authorities' handling of this matter? There seems to be a most extraordinary incapacity of the Government to deal with this matter in a simple, factual way when it has raised it to the highest possible level of public concern through the Prime Minister's intervention.

—No, I cannot confirm that there is any evidence linking Mr Blenkinsop with the sorts of allegations that have been made regarding drug running and the use of the vessel C-Ment. As to the question of the Prime Minister's knowledge of these matters, I am sure that his awareness of the intelligence interest of the Australian Federal Police-and it goes no further than that-did arise only in the last 48 hours or so.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. What are the prospects for increased trade and investment in manufactured goods with Thailand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I visited Thailand in March of this year and there was some concern, I believe, in Thai Government circles and the business community that there was lack of recognition by Australian companies of the tremendous growth which has been occurring on a very steady basis in the Thai economy. The achievements there are very considerable. It is very encouraging that in recent months there has been a considerable increase in interest by Australian companies in that growth rate, which has consistently been 5 per cent to 6 per cent for most of this decade.

ANSWER.PARA: I must make the point that, although Thailand has traditionally been an agricultural economy, manufacturing now accounts for about one-quarter of Thailand's gross domestic product and about 60 per cent of its exports. In the past two or three years, Australia's imports from Thailand increased at an annual average rate of about 50 per cent. Our exports, on the other hand, have grown at a much slower rate, less than 10 per cent annually, and we run a trade deficit with Thailand. Other regional economies are responding actively to the opportunities in Thailand and the restructuring of the Thai economy. For example, Japan and Taiwan have been investing very heavily in the manufacturing sector there. I personally see the best prospects for Australia in areas such as telecommunications, agricultural equipment and services, port development, materials handling and services and some equipment for new power stations. It is encouraging that earlier this year General Motors-Holden's Ltd began to market the Commodore in Bangkok again after, I think, some 10 years absence from that market. I think that should be seen as a symbol of the resurgence of Australian manufacturing and the renewed competitiveness of some of our industries.

There are several large Australian manufacturers operating in Thailand: for example, Ansell, Safcol and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, which already have factories in Thailand or are planning to establish them there. This is also a promising development. More recently the Australia-Thai Business Co-operation Committee had a very successful meeting in Thailand, attended by about 30 Australian companies and some 70 Thai companies. That meeting was held in July. It was regarded as very successful and there will be continuing meetings of that body. I expect that Australian Ministers will lead at least two business missions to Thailand in 1989. In summary, the opportunities are enormous for Australian companies and they should be encouraged in every way to take part in both investment and trade activities with Thailand.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications to question on notice No. 410 standing in my name as of 1 June 1988, which is still unanswered. As this matter has developed an additional urgency with the imminent return to seasonal service of airships over northern Sydney suburbs, and with the intensification of the unpleasant conditions being experienced by the residents of north Sydney due to propeller-driven aircraft and helicopters, I ask the following question: Is the Minister aware of any environmental impact statements having been undertaken by either Federal or State authorities on the question of noise caused by aircraft, helicopters or airships over northern suburbs of Sydney? Does the Department normally undertake environmental impact statements on the noise produced by aircraft, helicopters and airships; if not, why not? Would the Minister not agree that the residents of the northern Sydney suburbs have incurred, without their having had the opportunity to put their feelings to the relevant departments, a degree of noise pollution normally associated with living in close proximity to a major airport? Is the Minister aware of proposals for floating and fixed helipads in and around Sydney Harbour? Could the Minister inform the Senate of the authority under which airships have been operating in Sydney and the date on which this authority imposed regulations governing their operations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first two parts of the question, I am informed that formal environmental impact statements have not been prepared in relation to the operations of aircraft, helicopters and airships over the northern suburbs of Sydney. However, the then Department of Aviation undertook an environmental assessment of the noise impact of proposed helicopter routes in the Sydney Harbour and north Sydney area. It also undertook noise measurement studies in relation to the operation of helicopters and airships. While it was concluded from these studies that the operations would be likely to give rise to complaints by some residents, the overall assessment was that the environmental impact would not be significant.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the third part of the question, the noise levels generated over the northern suburbs of Sydney by helicopters and airships cannot, I am advised, reasonably be compared with the very much louder noise levels experienced by the residents of suburbs in close proximity to the very busy Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Fourthly, I am aware of proposals for floating and fixed helipads in and around Sydney Harbour. The matter is one largely for the State Government. The Civil Aviation Authority sets certain operational standards for helipads which must be met before operations will be permitted, but the siting of the helipads and the associated environmental effects are the responsibility of the State.

Finally, there are no special requirements for the operation of airships. They are treated the same as any other aircraft and their operation is governed by the Civil Aviation (Offenders on International Aircraft) Act and the civil aviation regulations. Airships Pacific Pty Ltd was first authorised to operate in January 1987 and has an air operation certificate which entitles the company to operate its airships commercially, as with other aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I direct the Minister to the second part of my question, which was: does the Department normally undertake environmental impact statements? The Minister has made reference to environmental assessments. I ask the Minister: Is there provision under the procedure of environmental assessment for formal community reaction to that assessment? It would seem that there has been no provision for the thousands rather than the few northern Sydney suburban residents to react.

—I will seek what further information the Minister wants to provide in relation to that. But the question is so general-does the Department normally undertake environmental impact statements on the noise produced by aircraft, helicopters and airships-that I think it is incapable of answer. There are provisions under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act for assessments to be conducted in particular circumstances where the exercise of Commonwealth powers is involved. Those procedures are well known and well set out in the legislation, with which I am sure Senator McLean is familiar. If one is going to build with Commonwealth money a new airport somewhere, obviously those provisions are potentially triggered. But in the context of the question, I do not believe there is any legal obligation. The practical resolution of the matter is that it depends on case by case circumstances, and in this instance it has been as I have described it.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to seek information from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs relating to the matters that were raised by way of question yesterday and the day before. TALK.START.PARA: —But he is not the Chairman of the ADC.

—We are getting the information in the proper way, Senator. The Minister was not aware whether the board of commissioners sought legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department in relation to the purported removal of Mr Mick O'Brien from the position of General Manager of the ADC, nor was the Minister aware whether the Public Service Commission was consulted on the proposed appointment of Mr Cedric Wyatt. —Has the Minister for Justice seen news reports of the indictment of a major international bank on charges of taking part in a worldwide drug money laundering ring, particularly dealing with the profits of cocaine smugglers? What steps is the Federal Government taking to combat the smuggling of cocaine into Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is becoming apparent to law enforcement agencies that Australia faces a much more vigorous push by South American cocaine producers to open up larger markets in this country. To the extent that northern American and European markets are becoming saturated, our intelligence suggests that Australia has been targeted as a market to exploit. Being concerned, as we are-and I am referring not only to the Federal law enforcement authorities and Government but also to my colleagues in the States, as evidenced by the fact that at the last meeting of the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy held in Brisbane last Friday a matter was put on the agenda for our next meeting seeking a very full briefing on this matter-the fact is that the spreading of the use of this drug into a broader socioeconomic spectrum, into sections of society which formerly favoured heroin and cannabis, is of just as great concern to the Health Ministers as it is to the law enforcement Ministers.

ANSWER.PARA: We aim to upgrade our attack on drug trafficking in relation to the smuggling of cocaine into Australia. We are actively considering the establishment of an Australian Federal Police (AFP) liaison officer post in South America. The network of overseas liaison officers has been one of the great successes of the Australian Federal Police. Only last week in Sydney an estimated $6m worth of heroin was seized in an operation which directly resulted from AFP liaison work in Singapore. It is thought that the expansion of that liaison network expertise and capability into South America would be a very useful response to the fact of, and concern about, cocaine flowing westward across the Pacific. This proposal is in harmony with the recent report of Mr Justice Stewart, the head of the National Crime Authority, who recently returned from a visit to South America, amongst other destinations. I believe that it is a very good response by the AFP in relation to this very disturbing matter.

The laundering of illegal profits that can be derived from the sale of cocaine is something which needs to be attacked, as suggest- ed in Senator Giles's question. This Parliament, in passing the proceeds of crime legislation, introduced an offence of money laundering. The cash transactions reports legislation, which has been in operation since 1 July, makes it an offence for persons to operate bank accounts in false names. In these ways the Parliament, in that sense in cooperation with the Government and in harmony with the wishes of the community, is engaging in a fight against criminal activity in the drug smuggling area which I believe is beginning to have some good results. Naturally, we have to maintain our vigilance and be creative in our responses, and I believe that the Federal law enforcement agencies are acquitting themselves well in that regard.

—Did the Minister representing the Treasurer hear the AM program on Monday morning in which the Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, asserted that improved productivity is the only way to improve average living standards in Australia? Is this statement true, and what action is the Government currently undertaking to improve average living standards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did hear the discredited former Treasurer on the wireless on Monday morning.
—Wireless?

—Yes, the wireless. That is proper English, uncorrupted by North American cultural imperialism. He said that he agreed with what I had said in a speech in Adelaide the previous Friday-that the only way to improve living standards was through increased productivity. Of course that is not what I said at all. I said:

ANSWER.PARA: Essentially average living standards in the long term are determined by three things: the terms of trade, the level of employment relative to the size of the population, and productivity.

By definition, in the long term those three factors are what determine the average standard of living. Mr Howard chose to refer to only one. I explicitly did not say that increasing productivity is the only way of improving average living standards. Of course, there is nothing new in a bit of misrepresentation; indeed Senator Stone accused me privately a couple of weeks ago of grossly misrepresenting something he had said. If not misrepresentation then certainly selective quotation is quite common in politics. So I am not particularly alarmed by the comments of Mr Howard. But what does alarm me is the ignorance the Leader of the Opposition displayed in making that statement. Even after five years as Treasurer he has apparently failed to pick up some of the most basic economic logic. It is no wonder that Senator Stone despaired of him and decided he was ineducable and being guided or advised by a meretricious player to boot. It is true, as I did say, that increased output per worker, or labour productivity, is one of the bases for sustainable improvements in average living standards, but there are other factors. Even Mr Howard and the meretricious player should be able to understand--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The Minister has chosen to use the term `meretricious' on a number of occasions to cast reflection on Dr Hewson. The definition of that term in the Macquarie Dictionary states, in part, `of, pertaining to, or characteristic of a prostitute'. That is unparliamentary language and I ask that the Minister withdraw.
—Order! I do not regard the term as unparliamentary.

—I did not mention any names, but if Senator Bishop has any complaint about a former adviser being described as a meretricious player, I suggest she take it up with Senator Stone, who in fact is the author of the remark, charge or whatever one likes to regard it as. I do thank Senator Bishop, however, for having placed on record precisely what meretricious person, or player, is-I think she cited the Macquarie Dictionary, but various other dictionaries have a similar definition-therefore identifying for the whole world what Senator Stone thinks of the Opposition finance spokesman.
—He was misquoted. He said `meritorious'.

—He did not. He said `meretricious'. I understand that when Senator Stone wrote that letter containing that succinct definition of Dr Hewson many public servants who received copies of it-I think there are about 69 of them altogether-were sent scurrying for their dictionaries to find out what `meretricious' meant.
—Order! I think the Minister's answer is straying from the question.

—You are quite right, Mr President. I will cease doing so. Obviously if half the work force is thrown out of jobs, the productivity of the remaining half-again, other things such as the terms of trade being equal-would have to double just to maintain average living standards.

ANSWER.PARA: The last part of Senator McMullan's question asked what the Government is currently doing to improve living standards. The point I just made is particularly relevant to that. The Government is doing many things, including restructuring awards, which will have long term benefits. But the most spectacular contribution this Government has made to the improvement in living standards which has occurred over the last five years, as demonstrated by household disposable income, is the enormous increase in employment. Over the last 12 months full time employment increased by a staggering 230,000 persons, while total employment increased by 313,000. Total employment for the month of September as against the month of August increased by an equally staggering 46,000 persons. The enormous increase in employment is the major reason for the increase in average per capita household income over the last five years. That is in distinct contrast to the quarter of a million people who lost their jobs in the last year in which Mr Howard was Treasurer; employment actually fell by around a quarter of a million.

As I said earlier this week, measured household disposable per capita income in real terms fell by 1.8 per cent in 1982-83 principally because of that enormous decline in employment. To use the definition preferred by the shadow Treasurer, real household disposable income per capita net of capital sourced income declined in 1982-83 by a staggering 2 1/2 per cent. I repeat: in the last year Mr Howard was Treasurer, average real per capita disposable income net of capital sourced income fell by a staggering 2 1/2 per cent. Using the same definition, this Government has reversed that and there has been a net increase, after the correction for that 2 1/2 per cent lost in 1982-83, of 1 1/2 per cent.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Resources, relates to the greenhouse effect. In light of evidence that dollar for dollar investment in known energy efficiency measures is seven times more effective in reducing carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere than a similar investment in nuclear power, can the Minister clarify the Government's position with regard to the development of nuclear power as a replacement for fossil fuels to reduce the greenhouse effect; the implementation of efficiency standards in industry, transport and household energy consumption to reduce the greenhouse effect; the provision of adequate funds for research and development of alternative, clean, low risk energy systems to reduce the greenhouse effect; the provision of adequate funds for reafforestation to reduce the greenhouse effect; and financial and technical assistance to developing nations in the provision of appropriate technologies for low-risk energy systems and the preservation of forests to reduce the global greenhouse effect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share with Senator Vallentine a concern about the impact of the greenhouse, or global warming, effect on our climate and temperature and the effect that will have on other activities on this planet. The Government believes that the best way of dealing with the energy implications of that is to pursue a course of increasing our energy conservation and energy efficiency. That is one of the most positive initiatives that can be taken. It is central to this Government's philosophy in approaching the problem; it is reaffirmed in our Energy 2000 policy statement that I tabled in the Senate in April; and it is part of our obligations, as an affiliate of the International Energy Agency, which is a subagency of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, to pursue a conservation strategy in terms of our energy resources.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has put considerable resources into the promotion of energy conservation and achievement of energy efficiency. It has done that for some of the reasons that I have referred to and which were referred to in the question. But it has other longer term benefits for this country in terms of self-sufficiency of our liquid fuels and as a way of extending the life of existing reservoirs. As a result of our Energy 2000 study, I set up a National Energy Consultative Council on which all the energy organisations and industries, as well as State governments, have been invited to serve. I have also invited the Australian Conservation Foundation to serve on that body. The first item that I as Minister have referred to it for consideration is the implications of the greenhouse effect on our energy strategy.

As to Senator Vallentine's particular question, it is true that the advocates of nuclear energy argue that this is a way of ameliorating the impact of the greenhouse effect. I note that. I find those comments interesting. However, I observe that it is not as simple a panacea as that. I cannot support the comparisons put by the honourable senator in the early part of her question but I can say, from our own calculations, that if nuclear energy were doubled worldwide at the expense of coal or oil energy sources, the net reduction in the greenhouse effect would be only about 3 per cent.

In the May economic statement we allocated further funds for reafforestation. An additional $15m has been allocated over three years for those projects under the national afforestation program. That meshes in with our other soil and land conservation programs. This week I started the process of developing a forests accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the forest industries and the Conservation Foundation. One of the elements of that will be the establishment of plantations. I think that that too will add to the stock of tree cover in Australia, thus helping the area to which Senator Vallentine referred.

Finally, Senator Vallentine asked about assistance to foreign countries. The Government has already undertaken significant steps to assist countries in this region in monitoring and coping with the challenge of the global climate change. The Prime Minister announced a significant initiative at the South Pacific meeting last month to assist with the establishment of a sea level monitoring network.

The implications for our trade, in particular the implications for the kind of trade in services which depends so much on a confident personal relationship between individuals in these countries and ourselves--

Is the Minister aware of recent press reports concerning the financial difficulties being experienced by the Australian Confederation of Sport for the Disabled in its preparation for sending the Australian team to the Paralympics in Seoul? In light of these problems can the Minister inform the Senate of the level of assistance provided to the Confederation by the Government and advise what steps have been taken to assist the Confederation in overcoming its shortfall?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the difficulties which those associated with sending the Australian team to the Paralympics in Seoul have experienced.

ANSWER.PARA: The Paralympics are open to blind, wheelchair, amputee and cerebral palsy athletes. It set a target of $2m. The Federal Government's contribution to the appeal was $125,000 in cash in 1987-88. Should that be insufficient to meet the needs of the team, I will discuss with her on her return what other assistance the Commonwealth might be able to provide. On behalf of the Government and, I hope, all honourable senators and the Australian people, I also sent a letter of support to the team wishing them well in their endeavours.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Haines asked me a question, amongst other things, on the capacity of Australia's rural sector to benefit from the increased meat exports to European countries following the European Parliament's recent decision to ban United States beef containing hormone residues. I am happy to give her the answer that she sought. I am advised that the European Parliament does not ban United States beef containing hormone residues. The European Community does have in place a directive which effectively prohibits the sale of meat treated with hormonal growth promotants. That directive came into force on 1 January this year. Its application to third countries was suspended for one year. The European Parliament on its own does not have the power to ban meat exports from the United States or any other country.

ANSWER.PARA: There remain considerable differences over the ban. Like the United States and other countries, Australia is opposed to the ban on scientific grounds. The recent scandals within the European Community about hormone treated meat provide further evidence that the system as established by the Community cannot be effectively policed among its own producers. Unfortunately, the European consumer is not able to choose meat on the grounds of its wholesomeness, or, for that matter, competitive pricing. The European Community operates a highly restrictive and complex quota system for meat and many other food imports. Under the terms of such arrangements, Australia has few, if any, opportunities to increase its exports of primary foodstuffs to the European Community.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to authorise the Treasurer, on behalf of the Commonwealth, to guarantee borrowings raised by Qantas Airways Ltd to finance the purchase of three Boeing 767-300 extended range aircraft. The aircraft will be delivered in October, November and December of this year.

These aircraft, which are the latest development of the 767 series, will provide Qantas with greater flexibility in meeting the requirements of the rapidly growing inbound tourist market. Unlike Qantas' existing 200 series, these aircraft provide for first class passengers and carry 231 passengers compared with 208. The aircraft will be utilised primarily on the Tasman and Japanese routes, two of Qantas', and Australia's, important markets.

Qantas has brought forward delivery of these aircraft to meet the end of year peak demand for travel. The Company plans to operate 154 extra round trips this summer to accommodate the anticipated higher demand.

These extra flights will be in addition to a substantial increase in regular scheduled capacity. New schedules to take effect in November reflect an increase each week of about 6700 seats, equivalent to 17 jumbo jets compared with last summer's schedules.
In addition to the early acquisition of the 767s, the airline has arranged to lease two 747 aircraft, which will be in the Qantas livery, to help operate the supplementary flight program.

The provision of a guarantee for Qantas' payment of, and payment of interest on, amounts borrowed for these new aircraft and related spare parts and equipment will be limited by the Bill to $US235 million or its equivalent in other currencies. This represents 85% of the total project cost for the three aircraft. The provision of the guarantee does not involve the Government in any cash outlay, but does create a contingent liability for the Commonwealth.

The terms and conditions on which the moneys are borrowed will be subject to the Treasurer's approval. The Bill also provides for proper security to be given to the Commonwealth over such property as the Treasurer deems satisfactory, and Qantas is to undertake to maintain adequate insurance of the items under the loan guarantee, and to protect the Commonwealth against the sale or mortgage of the property offered as security. The Bill also allows the Treasurer to require the fulfilment of any other conditions he thinks necessary before he gives a guarantee.

The previous Minister for Transport and Communications announced on 25 May 1988 a new reform package which included the primary aim of giving Qantas directors greater commercial autonomy to direct the affairs of the Company. The appropriateness of further guarantees for Qantas aircraft is to be reviewed in the process of implementing that package. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

JOURNALISTS OFFEND PEACOCK'S MODESTY
By CARMEL McCAULEY, Canberra

Mr Andrew Peacock, known for his attention to appearance, has complained that workers at the new Parliament House-particularly journalists-attend aerobic classes next to the swimming pool in which he and other members swim.
Mr Peacock's complaint resulted in the aerobics classes being cancelled indefinitely yesterday, and a vital question being raised: do the aerobic pupils really peep at the swimmers?
The only politician to attend the aerobic classes regularly, Mrs Ros Kelly, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, said no one in the classes was interested in who was in the swimming pool.
``I think the whole thing is absolute nonsense. You're not there to perv on other members' bodies,'' she said yesterday.
``I'm too busy sweating and puffing to notice who's next to me or who's in the swimming pool. All you can see anyway is the top of their heads.''
She would be discussing the issue with the Speaker, Mrs Child, to ensure that a new room for aerobics was found, but said: ``It seems a nonsense to have a facility and then not to use it''.

The co-manager of the fitness centre, Ms Merryn-Lee Hibben, said Mr Peacock had been adamant that he did not like the aerobic classes, although she pointed out that very few journalists attended them.
``He was funny about the possibility that members of the media would be commenting about how the Members of Parliament looked in their swimming costumes,'' she said.
``He said others had complained to him that journalists were there and that they would probably write nasty things about them.''
The $1-million fitness centre includes a pool, two squash courts, a spa and a sauna. The pool is closed to the building's estimated 3500 staff members when Parliament is sitting.
A spokeswoman for Mr Peacock said she did not know anything about his complaint.

The statement read as follows-
Mr President, this matter was referred to the Committee on 25 August 1988 following representations made to a number of Senators concerning the effect of the changes to the plan on some fishermen.
The changes remove the rights of a number of fishermen to take southern bluefin tuna.

The Committee sought information concerning the reasons for the changes. It was informed that they were necessary to prevent a possible expansion of this fishery that seemed likely to occur as a result of the recent dramatic escalation in prices that can be obtained for this fish in the Japanese sashimi markets. Top quality sashimi grade tuna can sell for more than $100 per kilogram. One fish recently returned $23,000.

Southern Bluefin Tuna has, however, been severely overfished. Catches have declined from a peak of eighty one thousand tonnes in 1961 to twenty five thousand tonnes in 1987. Scientific studies indicate that the parental biomass, that is, the tonnage of spawning adult fish, has declined dramatically, possibly to as little as one fifth of what it was originally. There are major concerns that the decline in the parental biomass may have led to a severe reduction in the production of young fish. If this has happened, the stock may never recover.

The Committee is in total agreement that dramatic measures must be taken immediately if there is to be any prospect of salvaging this resource. On 6 October, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy announced that the three main countries which catch southern bluefin tuna, namely Australia, Japan and New Zealand, have agreed to substantial reductions in the global catch. The new catch limit is approximately half the previous year's limit.

The reductions announced by the Minister partially answer one of the complaints of the small fishermen, namely that they were being forced to endure all the cuts while the larger operators were apparently untouched.

A problem remained, however. Some smaller operators were going to lose their fishing rights totally under the changes proposed. While agreeing that catch reductions must be made, the Committee was concerned to ensure that the reductions were made equitably. I am very pleased that, following discussions with the Minister, a more equitable arrangement is being put in place.

The Committee considers that it is deplorable that the fishery has been reduced to such a parlous state, particularly when the scientists have been warning of what was happening for some time. There are other fisheries which are of considerable value to this country, including the yellowfin and bigeye tuna fisheries. One hopes that sufficient resources are being devoted to the study and management of them, and that the countries which exploit them do so in a more responsible manner than appears to have been the case with the southern bluefin tuna fishery.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National parties will be supporting, after amendment, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988.
