SPEECH.PARA: Let me inject a personal note into this debate. As a primary producer, a beef producer in the export trade, I certainly do not wish to see all of Australia's agricultural and pastoral exports put at risk, as they certainly will be when the luddites of the Democrats and their allies embark on a witch-hunt based on fantasy and supposition, as we have witnessed from the Democrats on previous occasions in this chamber in debates concerning the use of chemicals. As Senator Lewis said prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch, this will have an enormous impact on our export market, and it is not only the producers who will suffer. We have been reduced to bankruptcy by this Government. This country now has an enormous debt. As we say continually in this chamber, not only do we have this debt position but also our standards of living have gone down and everyone would now have to get a rise of at least $56 a week to compensate for the increase in taxation in the five years of this Government. So the country is in no position to suffer an attack on our export earnings.

The people who are promoting this reference to a committee seem to think that there are queues of buyers in other countries for our rural exports. That is not true. We move in an intensely competitive market. We sell on quality and price; we do not sell on friendship or any favoured deals at all. We face the rest of the world, and the rural export market is the toughest market of all to operate in. We operate in that area successfully and the last thing we want is to be stabbed in the back by a few ignorant and uninformed minds.

To return to the Bill before us today: in a nutshell this Bill has as its purpose `to provide national legislation for the clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals'. Secondly, it will establish the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), in his second reading speech, said that the Government had four basic objectives:
(i) to ensure that agricultural and veterinary chemical products perform as intended
(ii) to minimise any possible hazard to the public, the environment, users or to agricultural produce and livestock from the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals
(iii) to enhance the export market potential of our agricultural products, and
(iv) to enhance the uniformity of assessment and registration of these products within Australia.
The Liberal and National parties sincerely hope that the objectives of this Bill are achieved.

At present, the situation with respect to agricultural and veterinary chemicals is that there is no specific overriding Commonwealth legislation for the assessment and clearance of new products. There is a non-statutory scheme of clearance carried out by Commonwealth and State representatives in the technical committee for agricultural chemicals and the technical committee for veterinary chemicals. Since 1967 the Federal Government and the States have voluntarily looked at assessment and clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals prior to registration for use in the individual States and the Territories under separate State and Territory legislation. The Australian Agricultural Council and the Industries Assistance Commission recommended that clearance and registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals should have a legislative foundation at a national level. This was supported by the State governments, the National Farmers Federation and other farmer organisations, and the agricultural and veterinary chemicals industry.

The importance of this legislation is that in the future we will certainly face increased pressure in the form of more and more rigid specifications on chemical and herbicide residues in the food chain. As analytical techniques become more precise, smaller residues of chemicals will be detected in food samples. Buyers of food will have threshold levels for these residues. At present, many are measured in parts per million, but we will have very much finer tolerances in the years ahead. If Australia is to sell in the world markets we have to show, without any doubt at all, that our food complies with these stringent specifications. This legislation should go a long way to taking us down the path to meeting those increased standards.

As well as the consequence of chemicals on the food chain, a secondary matter is involved: the environmental issues. We are aware that some chemicals have a long term effect on the environment and that some chemicals and drugs have an effect that is quite different to that for which they are prescribed. Again, this legislation will do something to control the unwanted effects by careful research of products that are used in the agricultural and veterinary fields. It is worth mentioning that because these agents are in themselves biologically active. The very purpose of using veterinary chemicals and chemicals in the agricultural field is to improve the quality of the crop or the beast in some way or another. They therefore play an active part in the metabolism of the plant or the animals to which they are applied. In those circumstances, it is quite understandable that they have effects on other organisms that are not intended when they are initially employed. There is a very real need to look at the broad field.

While we are talking about the negative effects, it must be emphasised that, overall, the use of chemicals in the agricultural and pastoral field has had enormous benefits for mankind. It is terribly important that we maintain a sense of balance. We must be cautious and careful in the use of these chemicals. We must not be stampeded by the hysteria of quite vocal although minor sections of the community who say that anything that interferes with nature in any way at all-and the definition of nature among proponents of this argument is very vague and very woolly-is bad and we will all die a horrible, painful death. That is not true at all because mankind has benefited enormously from the use of agricultural chemicals. We could not sustain the population in the world today were it not for the increased food production that has come through the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. It is not only a matter of food; it is a matter of the quality of life. Think of the application of chemicals in the control of parasitic vectors and all sorts of human afflictions. The most common disease that the world has suffered from is malaria-a disease which has been largely wiped out through the use of chemical agents, although it is true that in some countries it is starting to come back.

Overall the benefits for humanity from the use of chemicals can be seen in the quality of our lives-in infant mortality rates and, above all, in human mortality rates. Whatever the proponents of the `back to nature' argument may say, the fundamental point that they cannot refute is that through this century, which has seen the application of chemicals to agricultural and veterinary activities, the age span has increased significantly on what it was at the turn of the century. That could not have happened had what was being done to the food chain been as harmful as some people make out. Therefore, I emphasise that while we support this legislation, we do so in a balanced, intelligent and reasoned way. We certainly do not believe that mankind is at risk as a result of what has been done in the past. We do think that it is time to move on and adopt more sophisticated techniques in so far as they are possible.

The legislation also sets up a council to administer it. That council will be composed of up to 12 part time members-a chairman from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, a member from each participating State or Territory in the Commonwealth, one member representing the National Health and Medical Research Council, one member representing both the Australian Environment Council and the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers, and one member representing the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. We have no objection to the membership of that council but we think that it does not go far enough. There is no representation at all of the users of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. It is absolutely indefensible that the Minister should put forward a proposition in which the clients are denied a say in what is going on. There should be at least two members from the agricultural and pastoral community, one representing the agricultural side and one the pastoral side. I am surprised that the Minister has not come up with this.

The other people who should be represented are the manufacturers of the chemicals. There is nothing dishonourable or dishonest about being a user or a producer. They have legitimate and proper interests in the decisions of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council. They should be represented on the board because there are many aspects of the manufacture and application of these chemicals which, with the best will in the world, none of the members of the council could reasonably be expected to know. When this council comes into existence we would like to see its representation extended to include those people.

On a personal note, I hope that when this Bill becomes an Act it does not create a monster on the Australian scene. I remember very well the situation in the United States in relation to drugs in the medical profession 10 or 15 years ago. The United States Drug Evaluation Agency became so impossible to deal with that, to all intents and purposes, it was terribly difficult to get any new drug onto the market in a reasonable time. I hope the bureaucrats who will be involved with this have a cooperative point of view, not an obstructive one, in dealing with the introduction of new chemicals, because this is what it is all about-the licensing of new chemicals for use in Australia.

There is much more to the safe use of these agents than laboratory testing and stringent sampling. One of the things I have in mind is the provision of adequate directions on the chemicals when they are packaged. I find it difficult just to use lawn and grub killers around my domestic garden. I have enough educational background to be able to prescribe drugs for human beings, but I find it hard to read the directions on a can of weedkiller. One of the things the Council ought to do is direct that the instructions on these materials are printed in plain English and that measures, quantities and mixing techniques are in practical terms, so that people who want to use the agents safely can do so, particularly if they do not have much education.

At the end of the day we have to recognise that no one can stop people who are uninformed and irresponsible and who, either through ignorance or commission, use agents in an inappropriate way. One of the ways to move to control that is to package things in bigger sizes so that they cannot be used randomly or capriciously, but even that has its limitations.

They are some of the matters that I hope the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council will turn its mind to. Some of the people who will be using these chemicals, the people who are busy, who are getting on with the job, may have spent a lifetime devoted to rural pursuits with not too many years in higher education. It is important that we go down the path of developing better testing techniques so that the Australian export industries in the pastoral and agricultural fields, which still provide nearly half our export earnings, can be competitive in the export market.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, we sell on the export market on price and on quality, and that means we have to be super-efficient. It is not for the rural industries to get protection in the form of tariff loadings. It is not for rural Australia to have the 140 per cent tariff protection that, for example, the clothing, textile and footwear industries have. We have to produce a product which has to be better than anyone else's, and we have to be able to deliver it into overseas markets, without any support at all, at the best price. In attaining that goal, maximum production, whether in the grains industry, the meat industry or any of the protein industries, and maximum efficiency are absolutely essential. That is the real relevance of this Bill before us.

What we have had up to the present is a loose agreement between the Commonwealth and State governments, with individual licensing agreements for the release of the chemicals into each State. There is no agreed national standard. That means that the producers of the chemicals have very high costs in meeting at least six different standards in this country, because there is no reciprocity between the States on this matter. This Bill seeks to overcome that. It will go a long way to avoiding the problems that we had over 12 months ago with the pesticide residues in beef. We found that there was a very wide variation in the legislative controls that were in existence on the use of chemicals in different States. We found, furthermore, that there was a difference in the way that legislation was applied. Some States applied it and some did not. I can quite clearly remember that one State, which fortunately was only a minor supplier on the export market, claimed that it had no problem at all. The only reason it had no problem was that it was not looking in the right places.

If we are going to be a reliable supplier on the export market, we have to have national standards. It is the hope of the Senate that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill will bring that about.

The residue, of course, is found in the soil rather than in the grass. Because of the manner in which cattle graze they often consume up to a kilogram of dirt each day. It is in that dirt that dieldrin is found.

It is perhaps appropriate to reflect upon the state of crisis into which Australia's meat industry plunged last year owing to the organochlorine pesticide residue problem. For many years in Australia chemical residues in our food have been monitored by the national residue survey, a large component of which is related to meat products. Owing to what has been demonstrated to be a very ineffective system used in the national residue survey, a number of chemical residue violations were discovered in Australian beef which was being exported to the United States. The residues were detected by the Federal Safety and Inspection Services of the United States. As a result, exports of our beef to the United States were suspended and future exports were placed in serious jeopardy.

The industry of its own volition commenced an intensive testing and trace-back regime to isolate the chemical residue problem. The cost of this intensive program was met by voluntary levies from producers which were pooled into a trust account that went towards paying the cost of reimbursing meatworks for laboratory testing. I think Senator Panizza would agree that Western Australia had the most effective voluntary arrangements. An independent fund operated until March this year at which time the Government's compulsory $3.50 a head levy on cattle slaughtered was introduced by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. Under the scheme, all lots of cattle offered for sale were tested. As a result of the voluntary arrangements entered into in Western Australia, 400,000 tests were undertaken and over 1,000 properties in that State were quarantined. As a result of the intensive testing program, Australia's violation rate dropped from 0.4 per cent to 0.2 per cent. The pesticide crisis has had a lasting effect on the industry, particularly in terms of ongoing and increased costs. The Federal Government proposes upgrading the national residue survey and has deemed that the meat industry will carry half the cost required to fund the upgraded program and the annual recurrent expenditure. These funds will be met on an ongoing basis by the new slaughter levy imposed on the industry by the Government.

There is no doubt that had the beef pesticide crisis not eventuated last year nothing would have changed and this legislation would not be before us. That is despite the fact that, as far back as 20 October 1986, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) announced in a press release that clearances for agricultural and veterinary chemicals would be placed on a legislative basis. He made the following point:

However, he foreshadowed that prompt action would be taken; of course, it was not and we have seen the consequence of that. TALK.START.PARA: —After perusing the table honourable senators would readily agree that the present and past arrangements for chemical clearance and deregulation have demonstrated a total lack of uniformity. It is also useful to compare the action taken by the Commonwealth and the States in regard to products restricted or prohibited in other countries. The 1986 United Nations consolidated list of products whose consumption and/or sale have been banned, withdrawn, severely restricted or not approved by governments lists many countries, from all parts of the world, which have taken action against organochlorin pesticides over the past 20 years. By this evidence the ineffectiveness of the existing arrangements for the continual assessment of these chemicals is beyond doubt.

SPEECH.PARA: Hopefully clause 17 in the Bill before us will overcome this deficiency. This clause provides that where the Council becomes aware of any new information in respect of any chemical, it is able within the terms of the legislation, to reconsider its clearance. For this purpose clause 18 provides that the Council is entitled to take into account `the results of any experimental trial already carried out in a foreign country in relation to the chemical product.' If the Council is of the view that the chemical does not meet the requirements of clause 15, it may then withdraw the clearance given to that product. Accordingly, in this respect at least, the proposed clearance scheme would overcome the present defects. However, other criticisms-I say this in a charitable way-can be levelled at the existing clearance arrangements. Rhone-Poulenc makes the point that the process of clearance and registration is inordinately long. The company states:

Up to two years with a current average of around 12 months for a product to move through the clearance process is . . . a long time, especially when one has a market place . . . waiting for a new piece of technology.

The primary reason I am able to discover for the delay is the two-tiered clearance required, first at the Federal level and then by the State in which the chemicals are finally registered for use. The multiplication of time and effort is clearly inefficient and wasteful. It is hoped that the new Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council will streamline the clearance process. This will be done via subclause 4 (3), which provides for States and Territories to become scheme participants by entering into an agreement with the Commonwealth in the terms set out in the draft contained in the schedule. In effect, therefore, once the chemical product is subject to a clearance certificate issued by the Council, that product will be registered for use as set out in the certificate in all States which have become scheme participants. As a result, there will be a very satisfactory Commonwealth-State cooperative arrangement and clearance will require only one step.

However, the problem remains that the Bill imposes no limit on the decision-making time of the Council before an application for clearance is either approved or rejected. It was in the 1960s that chemicals began to be used on a wide scale in the agricultural and veterinary industries but the big progress has been in the 1980s. There was the introduction of those, well known now, knockdown chemicals which would allow one to graze one's land up to virtually a few days before one wanted to cultivate it. One could then apply this knock-down chemical such as Sprayseed or Roundup and within days one could plough that ground and in another day or two one could plant it. In this way one avoids the problem of soil breakdown from multiple cultivation. The other advantage is that one has kept using that ground for grazing. Of course one then starts off with a fairly clean crop. We have also seen the advent of pre-emergent sprays which are sprayed on the ground just before the crop goes in. As a result, the crop will come up totally clean.

I have used these pre-emergents extensively since 1981. It has been proven that one is able to increase the crop and get one's full potential from the land. I have done tests myself where the difference is 300 per cent. In other words, instead of three bushels an acre one can get a total of nine. If one has a dirty crop without the use of these chemicals the yield will drop to about a third. —No. I said the sheep industry, the pastoral industry, around Shark Bay. They are also attempting to interfere with the fishing industry around Shark Bay. They have interfered with the cattlemen in Tasmania and the timber-getting in the Queensland rainforest. The record is there to be seen. I have two points of concern about the machinery of the Bill. I have already mentioned that the States are to retain registration, and I agree with that. According to the report by the Standing Committee on Agriculture to the Australian Agricultural Council, part of the proposal for this legislation received in-principle support from the States. I hope that it will go beyond the in-principle stage. The Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council will determine the registration of chemicals. Presumably, the Council will consist of an agricultural oriented person from each State, a person from the Australian Environment Council, one from the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers, one from the National Health and Medical Research Council, one from the National Health and Occupational Safety Commission and a chairperson from the Minister's Department. But it appears that representatives of the most important sections of the industry-the farmers, the users of the chemicals and the chemical manufacturers-will be missing.
—Self-regulation.
—I would like to have written the legislation but I did not.
—That is the point. No such legislation was written by coalition governments.

—From that corner of the chamber Senator Powell will never get a chance to write the Bill. The farmers, the veterinary users, and the manufacturers are the ones pouring millions into the industry for the benefit of all. They are creating jobs. The rest of society makes full use of the benefits but then criticises those responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, the coalition supports the legislation-a measure long overdue. We look forward to seeing an improvement of the present situation and no repeat of the pesticide fiasco. As I have said, we support the Bill but in the committee stage we will be moving certain amendments that we think are needed for the proper running of this legislation and proper registration. The Australian Democrats are bent on a witch-hunt. We will do everything in our power to explain to the agricultural industry in Australia exactly what the Democrats are attempting to do. They are attempting to bring down Australia's greatest industries, not through a valued scientist such as Senator Coulter from South Australia but through the nuts that will follow him. That is what I am afraid of. It does not matter whether these nuts or, for that matter, the greenies have valid or scientific evidence to back up their submissions. But the scaremongering tactics that they will use to try to wreck the greatest industry that Australia has ever had do matter. For 200 years the agricultural industry has held that position; alongside the mining industry it is Australia's main export income earner. We will do all we can to make sure that those industries are not interfered with by these rebel greenie nut groups.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support all the remarks that have been made by the previous Opposition speakers-Senator Lewis, Senator MacGibbon and Senator Crichton-Browne. We have just heard Senator Panizza from Western Australia speaking in his normal forthright way on behalf of the people whom he represents. It does him great credit that he is looking after the people of Western Australia through the parliamentary process. He made a couple of remarks about the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Wilderness Society and some of the radical people who attach themselves to those groups. I do not make any attack on either the Australian Conservation Foundation or the Wilderness Society, but I remember well the time when I addressed them both about a year ago at the Seymour Centre in Sydney on the importance of the rainforests to Australia. In that address I mentioned that soil conservation was probably the most important matter facing this country in the environmental debate. I was booed and slow handclapped by those people when I said that because they were very critical of the Australian farming community and they did not recognise the contribution that that community had made to the wealth of Australia. I think that Senator Panizza has established that point rather well this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill was designed in cooperation with the States and the Northern Territory and it follows recommendations from both the Australian Agricultural Council and the Industries Assistance Commission. The legislation has been considered necessary because of recent incidents involving pesticides. We all know about that; it has been very well documented and much talked about in the past year or so. The Bill seeks to improve the present regulatory framework governing the registration and clearance of chemicals used in agriculture and for animals. The legislation will establish a national council for the clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The council will be responsible for coordinating the evaluation of chemicals proposed for registration for use in Australia and will look at the various parameters-toxicology, efficiency, dangers and so on. It aims to minimise the risk to users, agricultural produce, livestock, the public and the environment. We all know that the environment is very important.

I have often told the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, that we can have protection and production going hand in hand, but in a modern society we just cannot have preservation. A modern society cannot preserve something which has already been touched. So preservation is not something we can have in a modern society; but protection of a modern environment, yes.

This legislation will test the efficiency of manufacturers' claims and will provide a more uniform approach to chemical registration in Australia. Until now there has not been such a uniform approach. That may appear absurd in a country the size of Australia, but it is a situation about which little has been done until recently. It has taken a series of events to highlight the inadequacy of existing regulations. Therefore, I am pleased that in future there will be a national approach to the question of registration and the use of chemicals. That, without doubt, is something we all agree with. One would hope that the result would be the enhancement of the export market potential of Australia's agricultural products and not what the select committee the Democrats are proposing would do-put into the international forum all the accusations that could be made by radical groups around the country. That is what the Democrats want. They want some of their supporters to have the chance to come to a Senate committee and make radical comments and accusations. Mr Acting Deputy President, you know what accusations can be made at some of the committees we sit on together. Accusations are very easy to make but they could be very damaging to Australia's export income. That is something Australia cannot afford to suffer. We all know what our balance of payments figures are. I would be getting a little off the subject if I entered into a discussion of the problems of the economy, which is going down the gurgler under this Government.

The pesticide scare last year, when supposedly increased levels of pesticide were found in Australian beef exports to the United States of America (USA) and Japan, had the potential to decimate our most valuable rural export commodity. As we all know, whether we are riding on the sheep's back, the mining industry's back or the agricultural industry's back, our export markets are very important to our standard of living. Meat exports are expected to earn Australia some $2 billion this year-double what they yielded only four years ago. That $2 billion in one year is an income that this country cannot afford to lose. That income could be lost if the other motion the Democrats wanted to move in this debate, which was to be a cognate debate but which is no longer, had been put to us.

Whilst the USA is a strong market for Australia and the pesticide scare last year sent shock waves through the entire industry, it is by no means our only market. In 1991 Japan is to abolish totally import quotas, and Korea has recently decided to reopen its market to beef imports. Taiwan has an expanding demand for beef, and other South East Asian markets are also increasing their demands. Australia is in an excellent position to capture a healthy share of all these markets. We could lose the lot if our image is perceived to be that of a country with chemically infected products. Of course, we in Australia know that that is not the case. Australia produces some of the purest products in the world-in fact, I would venture to say probably the purest-be it dairy produce, vegetables or meat.

The two incidents last year in Japan and the USA concerning Australian beef will be remembered in the minds of some overseas buyers long after the facts are forgotten. I remember speaking to this chamber a year ago and criticising the Federal Government for not supporting Australian beef producers as much as it should or could. There was a general assumption, which the Federal Government did little to dispel, that Australian beef producers were irresponsible, chemical-happy farmers. No wonder the Australian Labor Party has been getting such heavy swings against it in rural seats, the Australian farmers are expressing their disappointment.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did you go in Groom?
—It was won by the coalition.
—Won by whom?

—It was won by the coalition. It was not won by the Labor Party and it nearly lost a seat a Saturday ago in another area. The Government failed to acknowledge that any chemicals farmers used in the past may have been used in ignorance; ignorance, because farmers used them believing they were safe. They had been approved and in many cases the farmers had been advised to use them by State agricultural departments. Whether the various State agricultural departments were in a position to know any better is open to debate. Certainly from records I have obtained from the Parliamentary Library, it appears that some States took years longer than other States to ban certain chemicals. One may ask why that was so. In any case, the result was little comfort to farmers. In my own State of New South Wales we have a publication which has been out for some time about pesticide residues and the stock owners. It is not only the farming community that can contaminate and put residues into livestock; many other people can do it as well. Lawn clippings and other things are also found to have residues.

SPEECH.PARA: Recent news carried a story of a potato and cattle farmer from Whittlesea in Victoria who has been forced to sue the Victorian Government because his property is being quarantined. He has lost his source of income as a result of using a fertiliser containing dieldrin recommended by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. The farmer had claimed that the Department owed him a duty of care to know about the dangers of using dieldrin and that it failed to keep up with research done on the subject. Had the various State departments of agriculture been more alert to the dangers of various chemicals which were freely available and which were being recommended for pest and weed control, this situation need not have happened.

And what is the situation at the moment? The Federal Government has already imposed a tax on the cattle industry to fund 50 per cent of the beef component of the national residue survey which was traditionally a service to the Australian community funded out of Commonwealth funds. This was, of course, on top of the millions of dollars that beef producers had already started to pay to clean up a problem which was not of the industry's making. Of course we still have over 1,000 farms quarantined and the future viability of those farmers is very much at risk. I will quote from Mr Allen Morley's address which he gave recently about the chemical industry:
AVCA-
that is, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association-

has opened its membership to the reseller/distributor sector of the industry. Many of these companies are now members of the Association and all of them are in full support of the accreditation scheme.
The scheme reflects a realisation on the part of the Australian farm chemical industry that it must accept responsibility for its products beyond the factory gate.
Not only must we improve the level of our services, we must accept a role in the education of the users of our products.

The chemical industry itself, I believe, has been responsible to the the people of Australia and I think it has played its part in trying to look after the chemical industry, although we probably all have some worries about the fact that some of the States did not always legislate the same way.

The irony and the injustice of the American scare last year was that the United States applies far stricter testing to our meat than it does to its own. In fact, American authorities only take somewhere between 1,000 and 2,000 samples across their entire 100 million head of cattle which supplies 90 per cent of its beef. This contrasts with the United States taking 4,000 samples a year from Australian beef which makes up only 3 per cent of its annual consumption. In other words, it is sampling us at a rate 6,000 times higher than its own. While we talk of chemicals affecting the beef industry, we must also remember the chemicals involved in grain production and horticultural production, which Senator Panizza has already mentioned.

Again, our own authorities test far more strictly for Australian food products exported than they do for imports of food into Australia. A recent Australian Broadcasting Corporation program highlighted the absurd situation currently in Australia. It claimed that Australia was `a bunch of amateurs' with the usual `she'll be right' attitude which would ultimately result in a major food contamination scare. It seems that of the $1,500m of food imported into Australia last year, only a small fraction underwent official chemical or other testing, even though previously many imports were found to be unsafe. There is apparently no coordinated system of monitoring and testing food products coming into Australia. So why should we even contemplate the Australian Democrats proposal for a full inquiry into the chemical industry in Australia?

Current statistics show that we have an average of 1,000 cases of food poisoning a week. We do not know how many are caused by imported foods. We do not know that we have problems with spices and herbs from South East Asia, and seafood from China, but even countries with good hygiene records, such as Switzerland, have sent us infected cheeses. Perhaps there is a strong message there only to buy and eat Australian foods which are most probably, the most chemical free foods in the world. Certainly, while we continue to have no Commonwealth food inspection programs, we are running the same risks with food coming into the country as we are with uncoordinated programs for chemical use which affected food exports.

I do not believe for a minute that the answer is, as some groups suggest, that we abolish all chemicals and revert to organically grown foods. Foods produced 200 years ago had just as many impurities, and probably more. We just did not have the technology to tell us that they were impure, so there is nothing particularly virtuous about so-called naturally grown food. I will quote again from Allen Morley's address recently before the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia. He stated:

Regardless of industry's repeated attempts to steer the media away from the emotional arguments and towards scientific facts, we are still perceived to have too big a vested interest in the issues to have real credibility.

Our own extensive market research clearly shows that the Australian public is far from convinced that farm chemical products are adequately regulated. Despite the fact that consumers are protected by the world's most stringent regulatory system, the perception persists that these vital products are an untested and unknown threat to people's health and the environment.

The industry is prepared to promote and defend the regulatory system to the point where this Association recently took the unprecedented step of paying to advertise that fact in a major metropolitan newspaper.

The chemical industry is playing its part. As a wheat farmer and a producer, I have a great respect for the virtues and dangers of chemicals, but I think that without the use of them, and if they were taken away from our agricultural community, we would all have much dearer foodstuffs and we would not have as pure and good foodstuffs as we have now. I do not believe any responsible food producer would think otherwise, but it is important that appropriate controls be put in place. While this legislation has flaws, which Senator Lewis has already mentioned-he will be moving amendments to deal with those-I think it is a move in the right direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988. The coalition is rather pleased to support this legislation that establishes a clearance procedure for the evaluation of new chemicals prior to their registration by the States. I might qualify my pleasure in supporting this Bill by saying that it is very much overdue. However, this is a mechanism that the events of last year showed is very much overdue.

SPEECH.PARA: While all too often this Parliament creates unnecessary and expensive regulatory systems of very dubious benefit, there can be no question that Australia needs a strong and effective means of assessing the impact of agricultural chemicals. We have learned the lesson that, even if it is highly debatable that chemical residues are a real threat to health, a world climate of sensitivity to chemical pollution means that the customers for our primary produce will turn elsewhere if dissatisfied with our standards. I think we really should have learned that lesson a long time ago, but it took the events of last year, when our export market was put in great jeopardy by chemical residues being found in beef, to teach us that lesson. The Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council which this Bill will establish will provide one-stop shopping for clearance and thus streamline the assessment process. Equally important is the development of guidelines for the use of chemicals.

As a senator for Western Australia, I am very conscious of the damage that has occurred to primary producers largely because these mechanisms did not exist and chemicals were used in Australian agriculture years after they were banned for agriculture in the United States. That is where we should have learned the lesson. The organochlorins that caused the residue problem of last year were in fact banned in the United States during the early 1970s. DDT was banned in 1972 and dieldrin was prohibited in 1974, but neither of those two products was banned in Australia until August of last year. In the most literal sense, we cannot afford to have a repeat performance of this kind of lapse. Government does have a responsibility to set rules and to establish cooperative mechanisms with the States to ensure that they work. It would not be reasonable to allege that the lack of previous action was the particular fault of this Government. The responsibility belongs equally with the State departments of agriculture that were actually recommending the use of dieldrin. I find that quite amazing, considering, as I have already mentioned, that dieldrin was in fact prohibited in the United States way back in 1974. So the State departments do have to carry a lot of the blame in this area.

What I do blame the Federal Australian Labor Party Government for is the lack of support given to the primary producers who collectively and individually ended up carrying the can for a failure of assessment of chemicals for which they were not responsible. Farmers who used chemicals according to official advice and procedures or whose stock grazed on land where they had been used have met the cost of a national responsibility, through increased levy payments and the quarantining of properties. Of course, we had a great debate last year about the increased levies in all States. In fact, in my State of Western Australia there was a very sensible system that the producers and the State departments were happy with. Everyone was happy with it except this Federal Government, which wanted to impose an even greater levy on the producers of Western Australia.

The cost to the beef industry, which earns $2 billion worth of exports for Australia, was $35m. That is a sizeable amount in anyone's language. Nationally, 1,000 farmers are still quarantined. In Western Australia, 250 farms have been released from quarantine and 340 are still presently under quarantine. Therefore, a total of 590 properties were affected by this problem. These are certainly not insignificant numbers, even if the issue no longer gets press headlines every day, as was the case. Unfortunately, all of these farms are concentrated in the south-west of my State.

The biggest problem that primary producers had at the time was getting answers out of any government instrumentality. These farmers have every reason to complain that the assistance that they have received from this Federal Labor Government is totally and utterly inadequate. It has never been my contention that when farmers have a problem the taxpayer has an automatic duty to come to their rescue, but unfortunately this Government does everything it possibly can to make sure that farmers get a hard life. As my colleague Senator Brownhill said a moment ago, is it any wonder that there are swings against this Government all over the place? The people of rural Australia are not silly. They know which policies are affecting them. This Government has experienced more swings in by-elections this year than one expects to find in a kiddies' playground. The Government will not learn a lesson. It will still not help the farmers. There is a very strong case for taking a sympathetic attitude to producers whose losses are caused not by their own unwise decisions, not by the fluctuations in world markets, but by the failings of governments that do not have adequate assessment and regulation of agricultural chemicals.

It is therefore relevant to this Bill to inform the Senate that the Federal Government has not cooperated with State authorities in Western Australia in a plan to give fair and practical assistance to those producers affected by quarantine-an action that puts them out of business as beef producers. The Western Australian Farmers Federation and the State Government agreed that an interest rate subsidy should be given to commercial loans of $50,000 for properties under actual or foreshadowed quarantine, provided that a commercial lender was prepared to advance the loan. The Federal Government, however, has not been prepared to alter rural adjustment scheme guidelines that would supply the Federal contribution to this assistance. The scheme regulations that preclude many producers from receiving this help are the requirements that their situation must in effect be so desperate that they cannot obtain commercial loans and that they must demonstrate long term viability.

Of course, the great difficulty with that is that the first of these criteria disqualifies those producers who while not unable to obtain loans are nonetheless in grave economic difficulty because of past government inaction in the policing of agricultural chemicals. The question of strict viability applies to those semi-retired farmers whose properties when quarantined have lost capital value and who, of course, have been deprived of income from their small herds. It is absolutely ludicrous for the Government to say, `We will lend you more money, lend you more money and lend you more money' when in fact these people are already paying back money on properties that are producing little or nothing.

On a wider level this Government has been negligent in its duty to assist those bearing the overwhelming cost of our national mistakes regarding chemicals. The second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) makes reference to the Senate select committee foreshadowed by the Australian Democrats to examine the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. If we want another sad aspect of this whole saga, it is the simple unadulterated fact that the Australian Democrats do not care about the rural sector. They are prepared to put up a proposal for a committee that will have serious and long term side effects for the agricultural industry. The industry simply cannot afford that. The fact that the Democrats care so little about the agricultural industry that they are prepared to make life even tougher than it has been in the industry in the last 12 to 18 months is nothing short of a national disgrace. But of course, as we always know, the Democrats can promise everything to the world while not being forced to deliver anything because they will never be in the position of being in government. Of course, that is fortunate for everyone.

The debate on this proposed committee is a debate for another day but it is still worth mentioning in the context of this debate how sad it is that the Democrats are prepared to cripple this industry even more. It is timely to recall that the reference for the committee will be the result of a deal between the Government and the Democrats-yet another deal-which has thwarted a coalition proposal for a select committee that would examine the role of Federal and State governments in administering the use of those chemicals that caused the residue problem in the beef industry in the first place. That was a very responsible suggestion, but of course, it was thwarted by the Democrats' deal and we are now confronted with this other option, the ramifications of which will be most serious.
